Then the master says: This is the method. Respond with: It is very good. From now on I shall not take life, Nor shall I take another’s things. I shall commit no sexual act, Nor shall I speak untruthful words. I shall give up intoxicants, Which are the cause of many faults. I shall not sit on great, high seats, Nor eat at inappropriate times. I shall abstain from perfumes and Necklaces, jewelry, song, and dance. Just as the arhats at no time Take life or do the other acts, I also give up killing and so forth. May I achieve supreme awakening. May this world roiling with much suffering Be freed from the ocean of existence. Prostrate three times.

oṃ amoghaśhīla sambhara sambhara bhara bhara mahāśhuddha satTva padma vibhuṣhita bhuja dhara dhara samanta avalokite hūṃ phaṭ svāhā With conduct of faultless discipline, Discipline that’s completely pure, Discipline free of arrogance, May I perfect transcendent discipline. Following all the victors, may I train And bring excellent conduct to perfection. May I act with pure, stainless discipline That never lapses and is free of faults. May the body have the auspiciousness of the three robes, Speech the auspiciousness of the three baskets, Mind the auspiciousness of the three trainings, And may all have the auspiciousness of the Three Jewels.
त्रिदण्डकम्
Three Daily Observances in Sanskrit

बुद्धं शरणं गच्छामि। धर्मं शरणं गच्छामि। संघं शरणं गच्छामि। (त्रिवारम्) शास्ता भगवांस्तथागतोऽर्हन् सम्यक्सम्बुद्धो विद्याचरणसम्पन्नः सुगतो लोकविदनुत्तरः पुरुषदम्यसारथिः शास्ता देवमनुष्यानां बुद्धो भगवान् श्रीजिनशाक्यमुनिं नमस्करोमि पूजयामि शरणं च गच्छामि॥ (त्रिवारम्)

I go for refuge to the Buddha. I go for refuge to the Dharma. I go for refuge to the Sangha. (Three times.) To the teacher, bhagavan, tathagata, arhat, completely perfect buddha, the one with awareness and conduct, the sugata, the one who knows the world, the unsurpassable, the charioteer who tames beings, the teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha bhagavan, the glorious victor Shakyamuni, I prostrate, I make offerings, and I go for refuge. (Three times.)
आर्यत्रिरत्नानुस्मृतिसूत्रम्
The Sutra of the Recollection of the Three Jewels

नमो सर्वबुद्धबोधिसत्त्वेभ्यः (बुद्धानुस्मृतिः) इत्यपि बुद्धो भगवांस्तथागतोऽर्हन् सम्यक्संबुद्धो विद्याचरणसम्पन्नः सुगतो लोकविदनुत्तरः पुरुषदम्यसारथिः शास्ता देवमनुष्याणां बुद्धो भगवानिति। निष्यन्दः स तथागतः पुण्यानाम्, अविप्रणाशः कुशलमूलानाम्, अलङ्कृतः क्षान्त्या, आलयः पुण्यनिधानानाम्, चित्रितोऽनुव्यञ्जनैः, कुसुमितो लक्षणैः, प्रतिरूपो गोचरेण, अप्रतिकूलो दर्शनेन, अभिरतिः श्रद्धाधिमुक्तानाम्, अनभिभूतः प्रज्ञया, अनवमर्दनीयो बलैः, शास्ता सर्वसत्त्वानाम्, पिता बोधिसत्त्वानाम्, राजा आर्यपुद्गलानाम्, सार्थवाहः निर्वाणनगर-सम्प्रस्थितानाम्, अप्रमेयो ज्ञानेन, अचिन्त्यः प्रतिभानेन, विशुद्धः स्वरेण, आस्वादनीयो घोषेण, असेचनको रूपेण, अप्रतिसमः कायेन, अलिप्तः कामैः, अनुपलिप्तो रूपैः, असंसृष्ट आरूप्यैः, विप्रमुक्तः स्कन्धेभ्यः, विसम्प्रयुक्तो धातुभिः, संवृत आयतनैः, प्रच्छिन्नो ग्रन्थैः, विमुक्तः परिदाघैः, परिमुक्तस्तृष्णया, ओघादुत्तीर्णः, परिपूर्णो ज्ञानेन, प्रतिष्ठितोऽतीतानागत-प्रत्युत्पन्नानां बुद्धानां भगवतां ज्ञाने, अप्रतिष्ठितो निर्वाणे, स्थितो भूतकोट्याम्, स्थितः सर्वसत्त्वालोकनीयायां भूमौ, सर्व इमे तथागतानां विशेषतः सम्यग् गुणाः। (धर्मानुस्मृतिः) सद्धर्मस्तु आदौ कल्याणः, मध्ये कल्याणः, पर्यवसाने कल्याणः, स्वर्थः, सुव्यञ्जनः, केवलः, परिपूर्णः, परिशुद्धः, पर्यवदातः, स्वाख्यातः भगवतो धर्मः, सान्दृष्टिकः, निर्ज्वरः, आकालिकः, औपनायिकः, ऐहिपश्यिकः, प्रत्यात्मवेदनीयो विज्ञैः, स्वाख्यातो भगवतो धर्मविनयः सुप्रवेदितः नैर्याणिकः, संबोधिगामी, अभिन्नः संस्तूपः, सप्रतिशरणः, छिन्नप्लोतिकः। (संघानुस्मृतिः) सुप्रतिपन्नो भगवत आर्यसंघः, न्यायप्रतिपन्नः, ऋजुप्रतिपन्नः, सामीचीप्रतिपन्नः, अञ्जलीकरणीयः, सामीचीकरणीयः, पुण्यश्रीक्षेत्रः, महादक्षिणापरिशोधकः, प्राहवनीयः, आहवनीयः। ॥ आर्यत्रिरत्नानुस्मृतिसूत्रं समाप्तम्॥

I prostrate to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. (Recollecting the Buddha) In this way, the bhagavan buddha is the tathagata, arhat, completely perfect buddha, the one with awareness and conduct, the sugata, the one who knows the world, the unsurpassable, the charioteer who tames beings, the teacher of gods and humans, the bhagavan buddha. The tathagata’s compatible cause is merit. He does not waste roots of virtue. He is fully adorned with the aspects of patience. He is the basis of treasuries of merit. He is adorned by the excellent signs. The flowers of his marks are in bloom. His behavior is always appropriate. The sight of him is never disagreeable. He delights those enthusiastic with faith. His wisdom is beyond intimidation. His powers are beyond oppression. He is the teacher of all beings. He is the father of bodhisattvas. He is the king of aryas. He leads beings to the city of nirvana. His pristine wisdom is immeasurable. His confidence is inconceivable. His speech is utterly pure. It is melodic. One is never satiated by the sight of him. His body is peerless. He is unstained by desire. He is utterly unstained by form. He is unmixed with the formless states. He is completely liberated from the skandhas. He is without the dhatus. His ayatanas are restrained. He has fully cut through the knots. He is utterly liberated from all affliction. He is liberated from craving. He has crossed the floods. His pristine wisdom is complete. He abides in the pristine wisdom of the bhagavan buddhas of the past, future, and present. He does not abide in nirvana. He abides in the ultimate perfection. He remains in the state of seeing all beings. These are the superior qualities of the Tathagatas. (Recollecting the Dharma) The genuine Dharma is virtuous in the beginning, virtuous in the middle, and virtuous in the end. Its meaning is excellent. Its words are excellent. It is unmixed. It is utterly complete. It is utterly pure. It is utterly purifying. The bhagavan taught the dharma well. It is seeing perfectly. It is without sickness. It is timeless. It guides fully. Seeing it is meaningful. It is known by the wise through individual direct awareness. The dharma vinaya spoken by the bhagavan was well explained. It is emancipation. It brings one to perfect awakening. It is without contradiction and has unity. It is reliable. It brings an end to movement. (Recollecting the Sangha) The Sangha of the mahayana is engaged in goodness. It is engaged in lucidity. It is engaged in truth. It is engaged in harmony. It is worthy of joined palms. It is worthy of prostration. It is a glorious field of merit. It is the great purification of alms. It is a fit object of generosity. It is always a great object of generosity. This completes The Sutra of the Recollection of the Three Jewels.
प्रज्ञापारमिताहृदयसूत्रम् ।
The Sutra of the Heart of Transcendent Wisdom

॥ नमः सर्वज्ञाय ॥ आर्यावलोकितेश्वरबोधिसत्त्वो गम्भीरायां प्रज्ञापारमितायां चर्यां चरमाणो व्यवलोकयति स्म॥ पञ्चस्कन्धांस्तांश्च स्वभावशून्यान् पश्यति स्म। इह शारिपुत्र रूपं शून्यता, शून्यतैव रूपम्। रूपान्न पृथक् शून्यता, शून्यताया न पृथग् रूपम्। यद्रूपम् तद् शून्यता या शून्यता तद्रूपम्॥ एवमेव वेदनासंज्ञा-संस्कारविज्ञानानि॥ इह शारिपुत्र सर्वधर्माः शून्यतालक्षणा अनुत्पन्ना अनिरुद्धा अमला न विमला नोना न परिपूर्णाः। तस्माच्छारिपुत्र शून्यतायां न रूपम् , न वेदना न संज्ञा न संस्काराः न विज्ञानानि। न चक्षुःश्रोत्रघ्राणजिह्वाकायमनांसि, न रूपशब्द-गन्धरसस्प्रष्टव्यधर्माः। न चक्षुर्धातुर्यावन्न मनोधातुः। न विद्या नाविद्या न विद्याक्षयो नाविद्याक्षयो यावन्न जरामरणं न जरामरणक्षयो न दुःखसमुदयनिरोधमार्गा न ज्ञानं न प्राप्तित्वम्॥ बोधिसत्त्वस्य प्रज्ञापारमितामाश्रित्य विहरति चित्तावरणः। चित्तावरणनास्तित्वादत्रस्तो विपर्यासातिक्रान्तो निष्ठनिर्वाणः। त्रयध्वव्यवस्थिताः सर्वबुद्धाः प्रज्ञापारमितामाश्रित्य अनुत्तरां सम्यक्संबोधिमभिसंबुद्धाः॥ तस्माज्ज्ञातव्यः प्रज्ञापारमितामहामन्त्रो महाविद्यामन्त्रो अनुत्तरमन्त्रो असमसममन्त्रः सर्वदुःखप्रशमनमन्त्रः सत्यममिथ्यत्वात् प्रज्ञापारमितामुक्तो मन्त्रः तद्यथा गते गते पारगते पारसंगते बोधि स्वाहा॥ इति प्रज्ञापारमिताहृदयसूत्रम् समाप्तम् सर्वपापस्याकरणं कुशलस्योपसम्पदा। स्वचित्तपर्यवदापनं एतद् बुद्धानां शासनम्॥ तारका तिमिरं दीपो मायावश्याय बुद्बुदम्। स्वप्नं च विद्युदभ्रं च एवं द्रष्टव्यसंस्कृतम्॥ अनेन पुण्येन तु सर्वदर्शितमवाप्य निर्जित्य च दोषविद्विषः। जरारुजामृत्युमहोर्मिसङ्कुलात् समुद्धरेयं भवसागराज्जगत्॥ ॥भवतु सर्वमङ्गलम्॥

I prostrate to the omniscient one. The bodhisattva Noble Lord Avalokiteshvara, looking at the practice of profound transcendent wisdom, saw that the five aggregates are empty by nature. “Here, Shariputra, form is empty. Emptiness is also form. Emptiness is not other than form; form is not other than emptiness. What is form is emptiness. What is emptiness is form. Feeling, conception, formation, and consciousness are also the same. Therefore Shariputra, all dharmas are emptiness: no characteristics, unborn, unceasing, no stains, no freedom from stains, no decrease, and no increase. Shariputra, therefore in emptiness there is no form, no feeling, no conception, no formation, and no consciousness. There is no eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind. There is no form, sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharma. There is no element of the eye up to no element of the mind. There is no knowing, no ignorance, no extinction of knowing, no extinction of ignorance, up to no aging and death. There is no extinction of aging and death. There is no suffering, origin, cessation, or path. There is no wisdom and no attainment. Bodhisattvas rely upon and dwell within transcendent wisdom without any obscurations of mind. Since they have no obscurations of mind, they have no fear; they completely transcend the mistaken and reach ultimate nirvana. All the buddhas dwelling in the three times awaken to unsurpassed, true, complete enlightenment by relying on this profound transcendent wisdom. Therefore the great mantra of transcendent wisdom, the mantra of great awareness, the unsurpassed mantra, the mantra equal to the unequalled, the mantra that completely pacifies all suffering is truth, for there is no deception. Know the mantra that speaks of transcendent wisdom: tadyathā gate gate pāragate pārasaṃgate bodhi svāhā This completes The Sutra of the Heart of Transcendent Wisdom. Do not do anything that’s wrong. Conduct yourself with utmost virtue. Completely tame your own mind. This is the teaching of the buddhas. Like stars, or seeing spots, or candles, Or like illusions, dewdrops, bubbles, Like dreams or lightning or else clouds: View all composites in this way. By this merit, may we attain omniscience, Defeat the enemy wrongdoing, and free All wanderers from the ocean of existence Churned by great waves of birth, age, sickness, and death. bhavatu sarvamaṅgalam
rgyun chags gsum pa/
Three Daily Observances

dus chen gyi dus la sogs par phyag 'tshal zhing bstod dbyangs sgrogs pa dang*/ mchod pa dang sdig pa bshags pa la sogs pa bsod nams kyi tshogs bsags shing gong du spel ba dang*/ 'gal rkyen sgrib pa sbyong ba'i cho ga'i rim pa bsgrigs pa la/ dang po rgyun chags gsum pa 'don pa la/

On special occasions, do prostrations, sing praises, present offerings, confess wrongdoing, and so on. In the ordered sequence of the rituals for gathering and increasing the accumulation of merit and purifying adverse conditions, the obscurations, first recite the three daily observances.
thog mar phyag 'tshal ba'i rgyud ni/
The first of these is prostration:

bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas/ rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa mnyam med shAkya'i rgyal po'i zhabs kyi rdul dri ma med pa la mgo bos rab tu gtugs te gus pas phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes pa'i tshig mtshams rnams la phyag bya'o/ /

Bhagavan, tathagata, arhat, completely perfect buddha, the one with awareness and conduct, the sugata, the one who knows the world, the charioteer who tames beings, the unsurpassable, the teacher of gods and humans: peerless King of the Shakyas, I touch my head to the immaculate dust at your feet and prostrate with devotion. Do prostrations at the end of each stanza.

yab sras mjal ba'i mdo las/ gang tshe rkang gnyis gtso bo khyod bltams tshe/ / sa chen 'di la gom pa bdun bor nas/ / nga ni 'jig rten 'di na mchog ces gsungs/ / de tshe mkhas pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

From The Sutra of the Meeting of the Father and Son: When you, the greatest of all humans, were born You strode seven paces on this vast ground And said, “I am supreme in this world.” I prostrate to you who spoke wisely then.
tog gzungs las/ rnam dag sku mnga' mchog tu gzugs bzang ba/ / ye shes rgya mtsho gser gyi lhun po 'dra/ / grags pa 'jig rten gsum na lhang nge ba/ / mgon po mchog brnyes khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

From the Ratnaketu Dharaṇi: You’ve the purest of bodies, the finest of forms. You’re an ocean of wisdom, a mountain of gold. Your fame resounds throughout the three worlds. I prostrate to you, the protector who achieved the ultimate.

'phags pa yul 'khor skyong gi mdo las/ mtshan mchog ldan pa dri med zla ba'i zhal/ / gser mdog 'dra ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rdul bral khyod 'dra srid pa gsum ma mchis/ / mnyam med mkhyen can khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes dang*/

From The Noble Sutra of Rashtrapala: You have the supreme marks; your face, a stainless moon. Your color is like gold: I prostrate to and praise you. Immaculate, there’s none like you in the three worlds. You’ve great and peerless wisdom: I prostrate to and praise you. And:

'dul ba rnam 'byed las/ mi mchog 'dul ba kha lo sgyur mdzad cing*/ / kun sbyor 'ching ba gcod mdzad de bzhin gshegs/ / dbang po zhi zhing nyer zhi zhi la mkhas/ / mnyan yod bzhugs pa de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

From The Vinaya Vibhanga: Best among humans, the tathagata Tames us and guides; he cuts the bonds and fetters. His faculties peaceful, pacified, skilled in peace— To him who dwelled in Shravasti, I prostrate.

legs grub kyi rgyud las/ mgon po thugs rje che ldan pa/ / thams cad mkhyen pa ston pa po/ / bsod nams yon tan rgya mtsho'i zhing*/ / de bzhin gshegs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dag pa 'dod chags bral ba'i rgyu/ / dge bas ngan song las sgrol zhing*/ / gcig tu don dam mchog gyur pa'i/ / zhi gyur chos la phyag 'tshal lo/ / grol nas grol ba'i lam yang ston/ / bslab pa dag la rab tu gus/ / zhing gi dam pa yon tan zhing*/ / dge 'dun la yang phyag 'tshal lo/ /

From The Tantra of the Well Established: Protector with great compassion, Omniscient one, you are our teacher. Immense field of merit and qualities, Tathagata, I prostrate to you. Pure, it causes our freedom from attachment. It is the virtue that frees us from lower states. It is entirely the supreme absolute truth. I prostrate to the dharma that brings peace. Liberated, you show the way to liberation. You are utterly respectful of the trainings. You are the sublime field, the field of qualities. I also prostrate to the sangha.

!_tshigs su bcad pa bzhi pa las/ skur gyur pa ni thams cad la/ / mtshan mchog sum cu gnyis mnga' ba'i/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas grags ldan pa/ / rgyal ba kun la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rdzogs sangs gang du bltams pa dang*/ / gang du byang chub la reg dang*/ / zhi ba'i 'khor lo bskor ba dang*/ / zag med mya ngan 'das pa dang*/ / bde gshegs gang du bzhugs pa dang*/ / 'chag pa dang ni bzhengs pa dang*/ / seng ge lta bur gzims pa yi/ / gnas de la yang phyag 'tshal lo/ / steng dang 'og dang bar dag dang*/ / phyogs dang phyogs mtshams rnams su yang*/ / skur bcas sku ni med pa yi/ / mchod rten rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes dang /

From The Four Verses: All your bodies have The thirty-two supreme marks. You are the renowned, perfect buddhas. I prostrate to all buddhas. I prostrate to the place where the perfect buddha was born, Where he reached awakening, Where he turned the wheel of peace, Where he passed into undefiled nirvana, Where the sugata abided, Where he walked, where he stood, And where he lay like a lion: I prostrate to them all. I prostrate to all stupas: Those above, those below, those in between, Those in the cardinal directions, those between them, Those with form, and those without.

With shared aspirations and immeasurable virtues, You undertook bodhisattva deeds together as brothers. You will accomplish your feats in this one fortunate kalpa. I prostrate to the thousand perfect buddhas.

From The Sutra of the Meeting of Father and Son: Having first generated the mind of perfect awakening, You gathered the accumulations for three numberless kalpas. You conquered the four obstructing maras. I prostrate to the bhagavan, the Lion of the Shakyas.

The Sutra of the Recollection of the Three Jewels

'di ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de ni de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas/ rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das te/ de bzhin gshegs pa de ni bsod nams dag gi rgyu mthun pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams chud mi za ba/ bzod pa dag gis rab tu brgyan pa/ bsod nams kyi gter rnams kyi gzhi/ dpe byad bzang po rnams kyis spras pa/ mtshan rnams kyi me tog rgyas pa/ spyod yul ran par mthun pa/ mthong na mi mthun pa med pa/ dad pas mos pa rnams la mngon par dga' ba/ shes rab zil gyis mi non pa/ stobs rnams la brdzi ba med pa/ sems can thams cad kyi ston pa/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi yab/ 'phags pa'i gang zag rnams kyi rgyal po/ mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du 'gro ba rnams kyi ded dpon/ ye shes dpag tu med pa/ spobs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ gsung rnam par dag pa/ dbyangs snyan pa/ sku byad blta bas chog mi shes pa/ sku mtshungs pa med pa/ 'dod pa dag gis ma gos pa/ gzugs dag gis nye bar ma gos pa/ gzugs med pa dag dang ma 'dres pa/ sdug bsngal dag las rnam par grol ba/ phung po dag las rab tu rnam par grol ba/ khams rnams dang mi ldan pa/ skye mched rnams bsdams pa/ mdud pa rnams shin tu bcad pa/ yongs su gdung ba dag las rnam par grol ba/ srid pa las grol ba/ chu bo las brgal ba/ ye shes yongs su rdzogs pa/ 'das pa dang*/ ma byon pa dang*/ da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi ye shes la gnas pa/ mya ngan las 'das pa la mi gnas pa/ yang dag pa nyid kyi mtha' la gnas pa/ sems can thams cad la gzigs pa'i sa la bzhugs pa ste/ 'di dag ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi sku che ba'i yon tan yang dag pa rnams so/ /

In this way, the bhagavan buddha is the tathagata, arhat, completely perfect buddha, the one with awareness and conduct, the sugata, the one who knows the world, the charioteer who tames beings, the unsurpassable, the teacher of gods and humans, the bhagavan buddha. The tathagata’s compatible cause is merit. He does not waste roots of virtue. He is fully adorned with the aspects of patience. He is the basis of treasuries of merit. He is adorned by the excellent signs. The flowers of his marks are in bloom. His behavior is always appropriate. The sight of him is never disagreeable. He delights those enthusiastic with faith. His wisdom is beyond intimidation. His powers are beyond oppression. He is the teacher of all beings. He is the father of bodhisattvas. He is the king of aryas. He leads beings to the city of nirvana. His pristine wisdom is immeasurable. His confidence is inconceivable. His speech is utterly pure. It is melodic. One is never satiated by the sight of him. His body is peerless. He is unstained by desire. He is utterly unstained by form. He is unmixed with the formless states. He is utterly liberated from all suffering. He is completely liberated from the skandhas. He is without the dhatus. His ayatanas are restrained. He has fully cut through the knots. He is utterly liberated from all affliction. He is liberated from craving. He has crossed the rivers. His pristine wisdom is complete. He abides in the pristine wisdom of the bhagavan buddhas of the past, future, and present. He does not abide in nirvana. He abides in the ultimate perfection. He remains in the state of seeing all beings. These are the perfect qualities of the bhagavan buddha.

chos rjes su dran pa ni/ dam pa'i chos ni thog mar dge ba/ bar du dge ba/ tha mar dge ba/ don bzang po/ tshig 'bru bzang po/ ma 'dres pa/ yongs su rdzogs pa/ yongs su dag pa/ yongs su byang ba/ bcom ldan 'das kyis chos legs par gsungs pa/ yang dag par mthong ba/ nad med pa/ dus chad pa med pa/ nye bar gtod pa/ 'di mthong ba la don yod pa/ mkhas pa rnams kyis so so rang gis rig par bya ba/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba legs par ston pa/ nges par 'byung ba/ rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pa/ mi mthun pa med cing 'dus pa dang ldan pa/ brten pa yod pa/ rgyu ba bcad pa'o/ /

Recalling the Dharma: The genuine Dharma is virtuous in the beginning, virtuous in the middle, and virtuous in the end. Its meaning is excellent. Its words are excellent. It is unmixed. It is utterly complete. It is utterly pure. It is utterly purifying. The bhagavan taught the dharma well. It is seeing perfectly. It is without sickness. It is timeless. It guides fully. Seeing it is meaningful. It is known by the wise through individual direct awareness. The dharma vinaya spoken by the bhagavan was well explained. It is renunciation. It brings one to perfect awakening. It is without contradiction and has unity. It is reliable. It brings an end to movement.

dge 'dun rjes su dran pa ni/ theg pa chen po'i dge 'dun ni legs par zhugs pa/ rigs par zhugs pa/ drang por zhugs pa/ mthun par zhugs pa/ thal mo sbyar ba'i 'os su gyur pa/ phyag bya ba'i 'os su gyur pa/ bsod nams kyi dpal gyi zhing*/ yon yongs su sbyong ba chen po/ sbyin pa'i gnas su gyur pa/ kun tu yang sbyin pa'i gnas su gyur pa chen po'o/ /zhes dang*/

Recalling the Sangha: The Sangha of the mahayana is engaged in goodness. It is engaged in lucidity. It is engaged in truth. It is engaged in harmony. It is worthy of joined palms. It is worthy of prostration. It is a glorious field of merit. It is the great purification of alms. It is a fit object of generosity. It is always a great object of generosity.

'phags pa kun tu spyan ras gzigs kyi dbang po byang chub sems dpa' shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa zab mo spyad pa spyod pa'i tshe/ rnam par bltas na lnga phung de dag ngo bo nyid kyis stong par mthong ngo*/ / 'di ni ri'i bu gzugs stong pa nyid de/ stong pa nyid kyang gzugs so/ / gzugs dang stong pa nyid tha dad pa yang ma yin/ gzugs dang yang tha mi dad do/ / gang gzugs pa de stong pa nyid/ las shin tu 'da' ste/ thub pa ni mya ngan las 'das pa'o/ / dus gsum du rnam par bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyang shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la gnas te/ spyod pas bla na med pa g.yung pa'i sngags/ sdug bsngal thams cad rab tu zhi ba'i sngags/ bden te mi brdzun pas na shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i sngags smras so/ / sngags la/ tad+yAtha/ ga te ga te pa ra ga te pa ra saM ga te In Sanskrit: Ārya prajñāpāramita hṛidāya In Tibetan: pak pa she rap kyi pa rol tu chin pay nying po I prostrate to the omniscient one. In this way, the bodhisattva Noble Lord Avalokiteshvara, while doing the practice of profound transcendent wisdom, looked and saw that the five aggregates are empty by nature. “Here, Shariputra, form is emptiness. Emptiness is also form. Form and emptiness are also not separate; they are not separate from form. What is form is emptiness. What is emptiness is form. Feeling, conception, formation, and consciousness are likewise. This, Shariputra, is the mark of the emptiness of all phenomena— unborn, unceasing, not pure, not dirty, not increasing, not decreasing. Shariputra, therefore in emptiness there is no form. There is no feeling. There is no conception. There is no formation. There is no consciousness. There is no eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind. There is no color, sound, scent, taste, touch, or phenomenon. There is no element of the eye up to no element of the mind. There is no knowing, no ignorance, no extinction of knowing, no extinction of ignorance. Thus there is no aging and death. There is no extinction of aging and death. There is no suffering, origin, cessation, or path. There is no knowing and no attainment. There is no non-attainment. Bodhisattvas rely dwell within transcendent wisdom, and in practicing there is no practice of mind. There is no non-practice of mind either. Since they dwell in the absence of those, they completely transcend the wrong and are able; they pass to nirvana. All the buddhas dwelling in the three times awaken to unsurpassed, constant, perfect enlightenment by dwelling in and practicing this profound transcendent wisdom. Therefore the great mantra of transcendent wisdom, the mantra of great awareness, the unsurpassed mantra, the mantra equal to the unequalled, the mantra that completely pacifies all suffering is truth and thus not false, so to speak the mantra of transcendent wisdom: For the mantra, tadyathā gate gate pāragate pārasaṃgate bodhi svāhā This completes The Sutra of the Heart of Transcendent Wisdom.

Refuge and Bodhichitta

bdag la sdang bar byed pa'i dgra/ gnod par byed pa'i bgegs/ thar pa dang thams cad mkhyen pa'i bar du gcod par byed pa thams cad kyis gtso byas pa'i/ ma nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad bde ba dang ldan/ sdug bsngal dang bral/ myur du bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub rin po che thob par bya/ zhes lan gsum dang*/

All my mothers, all beings throughout space, especially the enemies who hate me, obstructors who harm me, and all those who obstruct my liberation and omniscience, must have happiness, be free from suffering, and quickly attain precious, unsurpassable, complete and perfect awakening. Three times.

For that purpose, until buddhahood, I will employ my body, speech, and mind in virtue. Until death, I will employ my body, speech, and mind in virtue. From today until this time tomorrow, I will employ my body, speech, and mind in virtue. Three times

From The Way of the Bodhisattva: Until I reach enlightenment’s essence, I go for refuge to the buddhas. I go for refuge to the Dharma And Sangha of bodhisattvas, too. If you wish, recite the following words from the Saṃdhinirmocanasūtra: In its center is a great palace, blazing greatly with the seven jewels. Their great light-rays completely utterly fill innumerable world-realms. The palace has countless distinct features and is of immeasurable vastness. It is a place that perfectly transcends the three realms. It utterly transcends the world. It has arisen from supramundane roots of virtue. It is utterly pure and has the character of masterful awareness. It is the abode of the tathagatas. It has the Sangha of uncountable bodhisattvas. Innumerable gods, nagas, yakshas, gandharvas, demigods, garudas, kinnaras, great serpents, humans, and non-human beings move about within it. It is approached through the joy and great bliss of the taste of Dharma. It is a place where all benefit for all beings is perfectly accomplished. It is free from any harm by any stain of the kleshas. All maras have been vanquished there. It has the array of the tathagatas, features superior to all others. It is emancipation through great recollection, intelligence, and realization. It is the mount on which great shamatha and vipashyana ride. It is entered by the gates of liberation—emptiness, absence of attributes, and absence of wishes. This great palace’s foundation is a great king of jeweled lotuses adorned by boundless qualities. In its center are thrones composed of the various jewels of gods, nagas, humans, and others. Atop the thrones are mats made of priceless divine and human fabrics. On those have been placed various resplendent, pure, stainless lotus seats. That is the clarification of the palace and seats.
III. mchod pa byin brlabs kyi yan lag /
III. The Branch of Blessing The Offerings

!_de nas mchod pa gsal gdab pa ni/ khri de dag gi steng du/ rin po che sna tshogs dang lha mi'i gos sna tshogs las grub pa'i/ gdugs dang*/ bla re dang*/ 'phan dang*/ lda ldi dang*/ lha'i me tog man+da ra ba la sogs pa rnams kyi char dang*/ bla re dang*/ gdugs dang*/ 'phan dang*/ lda ldi la sogs pa mdzes par bres shing*/ logs rnams kyang rin po che dang*/ dar dang me tog la sogs pa'i drwa ba dang drwa phyed dang*/ 'phan dang lda ldi la sogs pas mdzes pa dang sa gzhir lha dang mi'i me tog sil ma bkram zhing*/ mchod yon/ me tog /bdug spos/ mar me/ dri chab/ zhal zas/ rol mo la sogs pa phung po gsum pa'i mdo dang*/ bzang po spyod pa'i smon lam las 'byung ba lta bu'i mchod pa'i sprin gyi rgya mtsho phul du byung zhing sna tshogs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa nam mkha'i khams kyi mtha' klas par rgyas par gang zhing zad mi shes pa dang ldan par gyur/ zhes so//

Then, the visualization of the offerings: Above those thrones fall such things as rains of parasols, canopies, banners, and bunting made of various jewels and colorful divine and human fabrics, as well as mandarava flowers of the gods. As well, canopies, parasols, banners, and bunting are beautifully draped. The palace’s walls are also beautified by nets and strings of jewels, silk, flowers; and by banners, bunting, and so forth. On the ground are scattered flowers of gods and humans. Bountiful oceans of clouds of excellent, diverse, inconceivable, inexhaustible offerings like those described in The Sutra of Three Sections and The Aspiration for Excellent Conduct, including offering water, flowers, incense, lamps, scented water, food, and music, utterly fill the reaches of space.
IV. spyan 'dren pa'i yan lag /
IV. The Branch of Invitation

!_de nas spyan 'dren pa ni/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas shAkya'i dbang po la sogs pa phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' nyan thos kyi dge 'dun dang bcas pa thams cad/ bdag sogs sems can thams cad kyi nyes ltung gi dri ma sbyang zhing bsod nams kyi tshogs spel ba'i slad du spyan 'dren zhing mchis na/ thugs rje chen pos bskul te/ deng dus la bab kyis dgongs par mdzad du gsol/ zhes dang*/

Then, the invitation: Bhagavan tathagata arhat completely perfect buddha Shakyamuni, all buddhas of the ten directions, and all sanghas of bodhisattvas and shravakas: I invite you in order to purify the stains of the wrongdoing and downfalls of myself and all beings, and in order to increase our accumulation of merit. I implore your great compassion. Now is the time! I pray that you consider me!

rgya cher rol pa nas 'byung ba ltar/ kye don thams cad grub pa 'dir gshegs su gsol/ kye lha'i lha/ kye kha lo bsgyur ba/ kye dga' zhing bde ba dang mchog tu dga' bar mdzad pa/ kye sman pa bla na med pa'i grags pa mnga' ba/ kye kun nas spyan mnga' ba/ kye mi mnyam pa dang mnyam zhing 'gran zla med pa'i yon tan dang gzi brjid mnga' ba/ mtshan dang dpe byad bzang pos yang dag par brgyan pa'i sku mnga' ba 'dir gshegs su gsol/ zhes dang*/

From the Lalitavistara: O Siddhartha, I pray that you come here! O deva of devas! O leader! O bringer of joy, happiness, and supreme joy! O renowned, unsurpassable healer! O you with all-seeing eyes! O equal of the unequaled, you who have peerless qualities and splendor, you who have a body perfectly adorned by the excellent marks and signs, I pray that you come here!

mtshan yang dag par brjod pa'i sgrub thabs gsang ba'i sgron ma las/ ma lus sems can kun gyi mgon gyur cing*/ / bdud sde dpung bcas mi bzad 'joms mdzad lha/ / dngos rnams ma lus ji bzhin mkhyen gyur pa'i/ / bcom ldan 'khor bcas gnas 'dir gshegs su gsol/ /zhes dang /

From The Sadhana of Reciting the Names of Manjushri “The Secret Torch”. And: For each and every being, a protector, You vanquished the ferocious hordes of Mara. You know all things just as they are, Bhagavan; I pray you come here with your retinue.

bcom ldan bskal pa grangs med du ma ru/ / 'gro la brtse phyir thugs rje rnam sbyangs shing*/ / smon lam rgya chen dgongs pa yongs rdzogs pa'i/ / khyed bzhed 'gro don mdzad dus 'di lags na/ / de phyir chos dbyings pho brang lhun grub nas/ / rdzu 'phrul byin rlabs sna tshogs ston mdzad cing*/ / mtha' yas sems can tshogs rnams bsgral ba'i phyir/ / yongs dag 'khor dang bcas te gshegs su gsol/ / chos rnams kun gyi dbang phyug gtso/ / btso ma gser gyi mdog 'dra zhing*/ / nyi ma las lhag gzi brjid che/ / dad pas spyan ni drang bar bgyi/ / zhi zhing thugs rje che ldan pa/ / dul zhing bsam gtan sa la bzhugs/ / chos dang ye shes chags bral ba/ / kun tu mi zad nus par ldan/ / tshur spyon tshur spyon zhi dag lha/ / thub pa skyes mchog thams cad mkhyen/ / shin tu legs byas gzugs brnyan ni/ / mchod pa'i gnas 'dir gshegs su gsol/ /zhes dang*/

Bhagavan, who for many countless aeons Trained in compassion out of love for beings, Now is the time to fulfill your vast aspirations By benefitting beings as you wished. I pray that out of the spontaneous palace Of dharmadhatu you and your pure retinue Will come, displaying miracles and blessings To liberate infinite sentient beings. Foremost master of dharmas, With a complexion like purest gold, More radiant than even the sun: I invite you with fervor. Peaceful and greatly compassionate, Subdued, abiding in meditation, Unattached to dharmas, with unobstructed pristine wisdom, With utterly invincible power: Come here, come here, peaceful and pure! Shakyamuni, great omniscient being, Your form embodies great goodness: I pray that you come to this place.

ma ga d+ha bzang mo'i rtogs brjod las/ tshul khrims rnam dag shes rab shin tu dag / dad ldan snying po nyan thos che rnams kyis/ / mgon med gyur pa bdag la rjes bzung ba'i/ / don mdzad thugs rjes dgongs par mdzad du gsol/ / zhes spyan 'dren rgyas bsdus skabs dang bstun pa dang*/

From The Abhidhāna of Bhadri from Magadha: Great shravakas, through your pure morality and wisdom, You are the mainstay of those with faith. I am without a protector. In order to care for me, I pray that you consider me with compassion. In that way, recite longer or shorter invitations as appropriate.

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga yon tan 'byung gnas las/ bdag dang 'gro la thugs brtse'i phyir/ / nyid kyi rdzu 'phrul mthu yis ni/ / ji srid mchod pa bdag bgyid pa/ / de srid bcom ldan bzhugs su gsol/ /
And from The Mandala Ritual of Manjushri: Out of kindness toward me and all beings, Through your miraculous power, I pray, bhagavan, that you remain Whenever I present offerings.
V. byon legs kyi yan lag /
V. The Branch of Welcome
bcom ldan 'dir ni byon pa legs/ bdag cag bsod nams skal par ldan/ bdag gi mchod yon bzhes slad du/ 'di nyid du ni bzhugs su gsol/
The Bhagavan is welcome here! We have such merit and good fortune. We ask that you remain right here In order to accept our offerings.
VI. khrus gsol gyi yan lag /
VI. The Branch of Ablution

spyod 'jug las/ khrus kyi khang pa shin tu dri zhim pa/ / shel gyi sa gzhi gsal zhing 'tsher ba bstar/ / rin chen 'bar ba'i ka ba yid 'ong ldan/ / mu tig 'od chags bla res bres pa der/ / ji ltar bltams pa tsam gyis ni/ / lha rnams kun gyis khrus gsol ltar/ / lha yi chu ni dag pa yis/ / de bzhin bdag gis sku khrus gsol/ / rgyal ba'i sku gsung thugs la nyon mongs mi mnga' yang*/ / sems can lus ngag yid gsum sgrib pa sbyang slad du/ / rgyal ba'i sku gsung thugs la khrus chab 'di gsol bas/ / sems can lus ngag yid gsum sgrib pa dag gyur cig / de bzhin gshegs dang de yi sras rnams la/ / rin chen bum pa mang po spos kyi chus/ / yid 'ong legs par bkang ba glu dang ni/ / rol mor bcas pa du mas sku khrus gsol/ / zhes khrus gsol dang*/

From The Way of the Bodhisattva: Within this sweetly fragrant house for bathing, Where the bright and lustrous floors are paved with crystal, Alluring pillars are aglow with jewels, And glistening pearls are draped in canopies, Just as all the gods offered ablution To the Buddha when he was born, In the same way I offer ablution With the pure water of the gods. Although the bodies, speech, and minds of the buddhas have no afflictions, To purify the obscurations of body, speech, and mind of beings, I offer this ablution to the bodies, speech, and minds of the buddhas. May the obscurations of body, speech, and mind of all beings be purified. I bathe the sugatas and bodhisattvas From precious vases that have been filled full Of water imbued with many fragrances, Accompanied by song and instruments.
VII. sku phyi ba'i yan lag /
VII. The Branch of Drying Their Bodies
de dag sku la mtshungs pa med pa'i gos/ / gtsang la dri rab bsgos pas sku phyi 'o/ /zhes sku phyi ba dang*/
With cloths that are beyond compare and clean, Infused with a fine scent, I dry their bodies.
VIII. gos rgyan 'bul ba'i yan lag /
VIII. The Branch of Offering Clothes and Adornments
de nas de la kha dog legs bsgyur ba'i/ / na bza' shin tu dri zhim dam pa 'bul/ / zhes na bza' 'bul ba dang*/
And then I offer them the finest robes, Well-dyed and most delightfully perfumed. That was the offering of robes. And:

gos bzang srab la 'jam pa sna tshogs dang*/ / rgyan mchog brgya phrag de dang de dag gis/ / 'phags pa kun tu bzang dang 'jam dbyangs dang*/ / 'jig rten dbang phyug sogs la'ang brgyan par bgyi/ / zhes rgyan 'bul ba dang*/
I drape Samantabhadra, Lokeshvara, Manjushri, and the other noble beings With fabrics that are delicate and soft And hundreds of the finest ornaments. That was the offering of adornments.
IX. byug pa 'bul ba'i yan lag /
IX. The Branch of Offering Anointment

stong gsum kun tu dri ngad ldang ba yi/ / dri mchog rnams kyis thub dbang kun gyi sku/ / gser sbyangs btso ma byi dor byas pa ltar/ / 'od chags 'bar ba de dag byug par bgyi/ / zhes pas byug pa 'bul ba dang*/

Like polishing the purest refined gold, I apply the finest scents, whose fragrances Waft everywhere throughout the billion worlds, To the radiant bodies of all sugatas. That was the offering of anointment.
X-XI. phyag bstod gnyis kyi yan lag /
X-XI. The Branches of Prostration and Praise
snang rgyan mdo'i thub bstod/

d.crumb: from the Sutra of Ornamental Appearances

f.d: Praises from the Sutra of Ornamental Appearances
de nas phyag 'tshal ba dang bstod dbyangs sgrogs pa ni/ spro na ye shes snang ba rgyan gyi mdo las 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyis sangs rgyas la bstod pa ni/
Then, the prostration and melodious praises: If you wish, recite Arya Manjushri’s praise of the Buddha from The Sutra of the Ornamental Appearances of Pristine Wisdom:

kha dog rtags dang dbyibs mi mnga'/ / rtsa ba mi mnga' gnas mi mnga'/ / mi 'gag 'byung ba mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mi gnas gnas pa mi mnga' ba/ / blang ba mi mnga' dor mi mnga'/ / skye mched drug las rnam grol ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / chos rnams kun la mi gnas shing*/ / dngos dang dngos med rnam par spangs/ / 'du byed mnyam pa nyid brnyes pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khams gsum dag las rnam par grol/ / mkha' ltar mnyam nyid thugs su chud/ / 'dod pa rnams kyis mi gos pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gshegs dang bzhugs dang gzims pa yi/ / spyod lam rnam pa thams cad du/ / rtag tu mnyam par bzhag mdzad pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mnyam par byon cing mnyam par gshegs/ / mnyam pa nyid la gnas pa po/ / mnyam zhing 'khrugs par mi mdzad pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mnyam pa nyid la zhugs gyur cing*/ / chos rnams kun la mnyam par bzhag / mtshan ma med la zhugs gyur pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mi gnas dmigs pa mi mnga' ba/ / shes rab bsags shing mnyam par bzhag / chos la mnga' dbang brnyes gyur pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sems can kun gyi sgra skad dang*/ / de bzhin gzugs dang spyod lam dag / skad cig gcig gis gzigs mdzad pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ming dang gzugs las rnam par grol/ / rgyu dang phung po thams cad bcad/ / rnam pa med la 'jug mdzad pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mtshan ma dag dang rnam bral zhing*/ / mtshan ma'i rnam pa rnam par spangs/ / mtshan ma med la 'jug mdzad pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / yang dag rtog pa rnam ma brtags/ / thugs yid rab tu mi gnas shing*/ / yid mdzad mi mnga' mi dgongs pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / nam mkha' 'dra bar gnas mi mnga'/ / thogs pa mi mnga' spros mi mnga'/ / nam mkha' mnyam pa'i thugs mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / nam mkha' dbus mtha' ma mchis pa/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de dang 'dra/ / dus gsum yang dag 'das gyur pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / nam mkha'i mtshan nyid sangs rgyas te/ / nam mkha'ang mtshan nyid mchis ma lags/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu rnam grol ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ngar 'dzin mi mnga' sgra mi mnga'/ / gzung ba ma mchis chu zla 'dra/ / chos rnams kun la mi gnas pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / phung po rnams dang skye mched dang*/ khams rnams dag la mi gnas la/ / phyin ci log las rnam par grol/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mtha' gnyis dag las rnam grol zhing*/ / bdag tu lta ba yang dag bcad/ / chos dbyings mnyam pa nyid brnyes pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gzugs kyi grangs las rnam grol zhing*/ / dam chos ma lags rnam par spangs/ / len dang gtong ba mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bdud kyi ming las rab 'das shing*/ / chos kun rtogs par thugs su chud/ / sgrib pa mi mnga' chos gyur pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / don 'tshal rnams kyis mchis mi brjod/ / ma mchis zhes kyang brjod mi bgyi/ / lan med tshig lam ma mchis pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gnyis kyi chos la mi rten par/ / theg pa'i rgyal mtshan kun tu btsugs/ / gnyis dang gnyis med rnam grol ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis yid kyi nyes pa dang*/ / lus kyi nad bzhi pham par mdzad/ / bsam yas dpe dang rnam bral ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lhun gyis grub par 'jug mdzad cing*/ / nyes pa thams cad rnam par spangs/ / spyod pa mkhyen pas thog drangs pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khyod dgongs zhi zhing zag mi mnga'/ / 'byung min 'byung ba'i bdag nyid can/ / gnas dang rtog pa mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dmigs pa mi mnga' thugs kyis su/ / kun gyi sems ni rab tu mkhyen/ / bdag gzhan 'du shes mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dmigs dang dmigs pa rnams kyis ni/ / kun gyi sems ni rmongs par bgyid/ / sgrib pa med pa'i chos gyur pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dmigs pa dag dang sems rnams ni/ / ngo bo nyid kyis mchis ma lags/ / bsam yas mnyam pa nyid brnyes pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gnas pa mi mnga' mkhyen pa yis/ / zhing rnams kun dang de bzhin du/ / sems can kun gyi spyod gzigs pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis lan 'ga' yang*/ / sems dang chos kun gtan ma dmigs/ / chos rnams thams cad kun mkhyen pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / chos kun sgyu ma lta bu ste/ / sgyu ma nyid kyang mchis ma lags/ / sgyu ma'i chos las rnam grol ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rdzogs sangs 'jig rten spyod mdzad kyang*/ / 'jig rten chos la rten mi mdzad/ / 'jig rten rnam rtog mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / stong phyir stong la spyod mdzad cing*/ / khyod nyid stong zhing spyod yul stong*/ / stong pa stong par ston mdzad pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sgyu ma lta bu'i ting 'dzin dang*/ / sgyu 'phrul chen pos rnam 'phrul zhing*/ / tha dad ma mchis snyoms zhugs pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / du ma ma lags gcig ma lags/ / ring dang nye la mi 'jug cing*/ / gdeg dang gzhag pa mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rdo rje lta bu'i ting 'dzin gyis/ / skad cig gcig la mngon sangs rgyas/ / dngos ma mchis par mnyam gzhag pa/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'dren pa dus rnams thams cad du/ / mi g.yo mya ngan 'das pa rtogs/ / sna tshogs thabs dang ldan pa po/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sems can rnams kyi brgyud pa'i thabs/ / mkhyen pas mkhas par gyur pa lags/ / de phyir mi g.yo mya ngan 'das/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mtshan ma mi mnga' lhun gyis grub/ / spros pa mi mnga' skyon mi mnga'/ / snang med bdag gi mi mnga' ba/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rnam rtog mi mnga' skyon mi mnga'/ / bdag gis bdag nyid ji bzhin par/ / kun tu mkhyen pa thams cad mkhyen/ / mi rten khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

You have no color, signs, or shape. You are without root or location. Unceasing, you do not arise. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Not abiding, you are beyond location. You are beyond acceptance and rejection. You are fully liberated from the six ayatanas. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You do not abide in any dharmas. You have abandoned the real and unreal. You have achieved the equality of perceptions. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You are fully liberated from the three realms. You comprehend spacelike equality. You are unstained by desires. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You always remain in meditation Throughout all actions, Such as walking, sitting, and sleeping. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. In equality you come, in equality you go. You abide in equality. Your equanimity is undisturbed. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You abide in equality. You rest equally in all dharmas. You have entered the absence of attributes. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Not abiding, you are without concepts. Having developed wisdom, you rest evenly. You have achieved mastery of dharmas. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You see at every moment The languages of all beings, Their forms, and their doings. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You are liberated from name and form. All causes and skandhas have ceased. You have entered the absence of appearances. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You are without attributes. You have abandoned even their appearance. You have entered their absence. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Your genuine thought is free from misapprehensions. Your mind does not abide in conceptuality. You are without mental engagement; you do not think. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Like space, you are beyond location. You are without impediment or elaboration. You have a mind equal to space. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Space is without center or end. The nature of Buddhas is like that. You have transcended the three times. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. The characteristic of space is Buddha. Space is without characteristics. You are liberated from cause and result. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You have neither self-fixation nor words. You are beyond apprehension, like the moon in water. You do not abide in any dharmas. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You do not abide in the skandhas, Ayatanas, or dhatus. You are liberated from error. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You are liberated from the two extremes. You have eradicated the view of a self. You have achieved the equality of the dharmadhatu. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You are liberated from all forms. You have abandoned all that is not Dharma. You have neither taking nor giving. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You have passed far beyond even Mara’s name. You comprehend the realization of all dharmas. You have become free from obscurations. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Those who know the meaning do not speak of existence. They also do not speak of nonexistence. They do not reply, as there are no words. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Without relying on duality You plant everywhere the victory banner of the vehicles. You are liberated from duality and nonduality. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You defeated the defects of the mind And the four sicknesses of the body. You are inconceivable and incomparable. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You have entered the spontaneously present. You have abandoned all that is wrong. Your conduct is always led by wisdom. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Your wisdom is tranquil and undefiled. You are not the elements and yet you embody them. You are without location or thought. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Your mind, which is without concepts, Fully knows the minds of all beings. You do not have the perception of self and other. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. The minds of all beings are befuddled By concepts and their objects. You have become unobscured. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Concepts and minds Do not exist in nature. You have achieved inconceivable equality. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Your wisdom, which has no location, Sees all realms and, in the same way, The actions of all beings. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Buddhas never, ever see The mind or any dharmas. You know with omniscience all dharmas. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. All dharmas are like illusions. Illusion itself is nonexistent. You are liberated from illusory dharmas. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Although buddhas act in the world, They do not rely upon the mundane. You do not have mundane thoughts. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Because they are empty, your deeds occur within emptiness. You are empty, as is the arena of your deeds. You are the empty pointing out emptiness. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. With illusory samadhi You emanate great magical illusions. You have entered nondifferentiation. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Neither many nor one, You are neither far nor near. You are beyond raising and placing. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Through the vajralike samadhi In one instant you achieved buddhahood. You rest in unreality. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. You, our guide, are at all times unmoving. You have realized nirvana. You have diverse means. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Because you know means for guiding beings gradually, You have become skilled. You therefore achieved unwavering nirvana. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Without attributes, you are spontaneously present. Without elaborations, you are flawless. Without appearances, you are without “mine.” I prostrate to you who rely on nothing. Without thoughts, you are faultless. Because you correctly know your own nature, Knowing all, you are omniscient. I prostrate to you who rely on nothing.

stobs bcu chu bo rgal ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'jigs bral 'jigs med stsol ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ma 'dres chos rnams nges par thugs su chud gyur pa/ / 'gro ba kun gyi 'dren pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / kun sbyor 'ching ba bcad pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / pha rol byon te thang la bzhugs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / skye bo ngal ba'i rnam 'dren khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'khor bar gshegs shing mi gnas pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'gro ba thams cad dag na sems can rnams dang ni/ / thabs cig bzhugs kyang thugs yid rab tu dben gyur pa/ / ji ltar pad+ma chab kyis gos par mi 'gyur zhing*/ / sangs rgyas thub pa khyod kyis stong nyid shin tu bsten/ / mtshan ma thams cad rnam pa kun tu rnam par bshig / khyod la gar yang smon par mdzad pa mchis ma lags/ / ston pa'i go 'phang bla med dben pa nyid lags te/ / dmigs med chu bo rgal ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sangs rgyas mthu chen bsam gyis khyab pa ma lags te/ / mi gnas nam mkha' mnyam pa nyid la phyag 'tshal lo/ / yon tan kun gyi mchog mnga' khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dpal 'phags lhun po 'dra ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes so/

I prostrate to you who have crossed the river of the ten strengths. I prostrate to the fearless one who bestows fearlessness. I prostrate to you, the guide of all beings Who has comprehended the unshared dharmas. I prostrate to you who have cut through all the fetters and bonds. I prostrate to you who have crossed over and abide in the valley. I prostrate to you, the guide of weary beings. I prostrate to you who have entered samsara but do not abide within it. You abide among all beings, But your mind is utterly detached. Just as a lotus is unstained by mire, Buddha Shakyamuni, you rest in utter emptiness. You have destroyed all attributes. There is nothing to which you aspire. Teacher, your state is unsurpassable satisfaction. I prostrate to you who have crossed the rivers nonconceptually. The power of the Buddha is inconceivable. I prostrate to the nonabiding equality of space. I prostrate to you who have the best of all attributes. I prostrate to you who are like a glorious mountain.
yul 'khor skyong mdo'i thub bstod/

'phags pa yul 'khor skyong gis zhus pa'i mdo las mtshan dpe'i sgo nas bstod pa bslab btus su drangs pa ni/
The praise in reference to the marks and signs from The Sutra Requested by Noble Rashtrapala and quoted in The Summary of the Training:

mtshan mchog ldan pa dri med zla ba'i zhal/ / gser mdog 'dra ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rdul bral khyod 'dra srid pa gsum ma mchis/ / mnyam med mkhyen chen khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rgyal ba'i dbu skra 'jam mdzes snum zhing bzang*/ / khyod kyi gtsug tor 'di ni ri rgyal bzhin/ / gtsug tor mi mthong khyod dang mtshungs ma mchis/ / thub pa khyod kyi smin mtshams mdzod spus mdzes/ / kun+da zla ba kha ba dung ltar dkar/ / thugs rje gang gis 'gro ba 'di gzigs pa/ / spyan mchog bzang po ut+pal sngon po 'dra/ / rgyal ba dri med spyan la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ljags yangs srab la zangs kyi mdog 'dra ba/ / de yis rang gi zhal gyi gdong yang khebs/ / chos gsungs pas ni 'gro ba 'dul bar bgyid/ / 'jam snum gsung ldan khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / tshems bzang shin tu brtan pa rdo rje 'dra/ / bcu dang sum cu snyoms shing thags bzang ba/ / 'dzum pa mdzad nas 'gro ba 'dul bar bgyid/ / bden gtam snyan pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rgyal ba khyod kyi gzugs dang mtshungs ma mchis/ / 'od kyis zhing brgya dag kyang snang bar bgyid/ / 'jig rten na ni tshangs dbang skyong de dag / bcom ldan khyod kyi 'od kyis zil du brlag / e n+ya'i byin pa mnyam med bcom ldan 'das/ / glang po'i rgyal po rma bya seng ge'i stabs/ / bcom ldan gnya' shing gang du gzigs shing gshegs/ / sa dang ri dang ngam pa g.yo bar mdzad/ / bcom ldan sku mchog mtshan gyis brgyan pa ste/ / khyod kyi pags pa 'jam zhing gser mdog 'dra/ / 'gro ba gzugs 'di lta bas ngoms mi 'gyur/ / khyod ni mtshungs pa ma mchis gzugs dang ldan/ / khyod sngon bskal pa brgyar ni dka' thub spyad/ / khyod gtong dul dang sbyin pa kun la dgyes/ / sems can kun la thugs rje byams thugs ldan/ / mchog tu thugs rje can la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khyod ni sbyin dang tshul khrims rtag tu dgyes/ / khyod ni bzod dang brtson 'grus dgyes rab brtan/ / khyod ni bsam gtan shes rab 'od zer mnga'/ / mtshungs med ye shes mnga' la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khyod ni smra ba ngan pa'i tshogs can 'joms/ / khyod ni seng ge lta bur 'khor du sgrogs/ / khyod ni sman pa'i rgyal po dri gsum sel/ / mchog tu dga' mdzad khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thub pa sku gsung thugs ni rnam par dag / pad+ma chu ltar srid pa gsum mi gos/ / khyod ni tshangs dbyangs ka la ping+ka'i skad/ / srid gsum pha rol gshegs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis 'gro 'di sgyu ma lta bu dang*/ / gar la lta dang rmi lam 'dra ba dang*/ / bdag med sems can med cing srog 'gro med/ / chos rnams smig rgyu chu zla 'dra bar mkhyen/ / stong pa zhi ba skye ba med pa'i tshul/ / ma shes pas ni 'gro bar 'khyams gyur te/ / thugs rje thabs tshul rigs pa brgya dag gis/ / de dag rnams ni 'dzud par mdzad pa lags/ / 'dod chags la sogs nad mang brgya dag gis/ / skrag par gyur pa'i 'gro la rtag gzigs te/ / bde gshegs sems can brgya dag yongs 'grol zhing*/ / zla med sman pa lta bur rnam par rgyu/ / skye dang rga dang 'chi dang mya ngan non/ / sdug dang bral dang smre sngags 'don pa brgyas/ / rtag tu na ba'i sdug bsngal gzigs nas ni/ / thub pa thugs rjes yongs su 'grol zhing rgyu/ / dud 'gro yi dwags dmyal ba'i 'gro rnams su/ / 'gro kun shing rta'i 'phang lo bzhin du 'khor/ / glen pa dmigs bu ma mchis mgon ma mchis/ / de la lam gyi dam pa ston mdzad pa/ / gtso bo mtshungs pa med pas gang bstan pa/ / 'phags lam de nyid gang dag sngon chad kyis/ / chos kyi dbang phyug 'gro ba'i don mdzad pa/ / rgyal ba de dag rnams kyis rab tu gsungs/ / 'jam zhing mnyen la yid du 'ong ba'i mchog / tshangs las lhag par mchog tu dga' bgyid pa/ / dri za mi 'am ci lha'i bu mo mchog / sgra de zil gyis mnan nas gsungs par mdzad/ / bden dang drang ba mi zad thabs tshul gyis/ / yongs sbyangs yon tan mtha' yas ldan pa'i gsung*/ / de thos sems can khrag khrig brgya phrag dag / theg pa gsum gyis zhi bar mchi ba bgyid/ / khyod la mchod pas lha yi bde ba ni/ / rnam pa mang dang de bzhin mi yi 'thob/ / mi yi bdag po 'gro la phan bgyid pa/ / phyug cing nor che 'byor pa chen por 'gyur/ / mtshungs med khyod la dad pa bskyed pas ni/ / gling bzhi'i bdag po 'khor los bsgyur ba mchog / 'gro la dge ba bcu po kun byed pa/ / rin chen rab bzang bdun ldan thob par 'gyur/ / rgyal ba khyod la mchod pa bgyis pas ni/ / tshangs pa brgya byin 'jig rten bdag po dang*/ / yongs su dga' ldan lha yi bdag po dang*/ / gzhan 'phrul pa dang 'thab bral rab dgar 'gyur/ / 'gro ba'i sdug bsngal rnam mang sel mdzad pa/ / mnyam med khyod la mchod dang mthong ba dang*/ / thos pa'ang de ltar 'bras bu mchis lags te/ / gnas mchog rga shi med pa 'thob par 'gyur/ / bcom ldan lam la mkhas shing lam mkhyen pa/ / 'jig rten 'di ni ngan pa'i lam las bzlog / bcom ldan 'gro ba dag ni 'phags pa'i lam/ / bde ba zhi ba rdul dang bral la 'god/ / bsod nams gter khyod bsod nams don gnyer ba'i/ / bsod nams bgyi ba rtag tu mi bas te/ / byang chub dam pa ma thob bar du ni/ / bskal pa bye ba mang por bas mi 'gyur/ / gzhan 'phrul 'dra ba rtag tu dga' bgyi ba/ / yongs su dag cing mdzes pa thob par 'gyur/ / dam pa'i zhing du lus dang ngag yid kyis/ / sems can dag ni rnam par dag par 'gyur/ / rgyal ba mchod pa'i mi yis 'di la sogs/ / yon tan rnam pa du ma thob par 'gyur/ / mtho ris thar pa mi yi bde ba dang*/ / 'gro ba kun gyi bsod nams gter thob 'gyur/ / khyod kyi brjod dang grags pa rgya chen po/ / phyogs rnams kun gyi zhing mang brgyar yang mchis/ / rgyal ba khyod kyi bsngags pa'i phreng ba ni/ / bde bar gshegs rnams 'khor du rtag par sgrogs/ / rims nad bral zhing 'gro ba thar mdzad pa/ / mthong na dga' ba thugs rje mchog ldan pa/ / bcom ldan dbang po zhi ba zhi dges pa/ / mi mchog dam pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bdag gis rgyal ba khyod kyi gsung thos nas/ / mngon par shes pa lnga thob mkha' la gnas/ / dpa' bo bde gshegs mtshungs par bdag gyur te/ / dri med chos ni 'gro la rnam par dbye/ / lha dang mi dang klus mchod bde bar gshegs/ / yon tan kun gyi mthar phyin deng bstod pas/ / bsod nams rgya chen gang bsgrubs gyur pa 'dis/ / 'gro ba sangs rgyas go 'phang thob par shog / ces so/ /

You have the great marks and a face like the stainless moon. I prostrate to you whose color is like gold. You are immaculate; there is no one like you in the three worlds. I prostrate to and praise you whose great wisdom is peerless. The Buddha’s hair is soft, lustrous, and fine. Your ushnisha is like the king of mountains. That ushnisha is unseen; no one is your equal. Shakyamuni, the space between your brows is beautified by a hair. It is as white as a lily, the moon, snow, or a conch. In your compassion, you see all beings. Your excellent eyes are like blue utpalas. I prostrate to the Buddha, whose eyes are stainless. Your tongue is wide, fine, and copper-colored. It can cover your face. By teaching Dharma, you tame beings. I prostrate to you whose speech is soft and smooth. Your excellent teeth are very strong, like vajras. There are forty of them; they are even. You tame beings with your smile. I prostrate to you who speak the truth. Buddha, your form is unequaled. Its light illuminates a hundred realms. Brahma, Indra, and the lokapalas of the world Are overwhelmed, bhagavan, by your light. Peerless bhagavan, your calves are like a gazelle’s. Your gait is like that of an elephant king, a peacock, or a lion. Your gaze rests on one yoke’s distance. You shake the earth, its mountains, and the wilderness. Bhagavan, your wondrous body is adorned by marks. Your skin is soft and of a golden color. Seeing this form, beings are never satiated. You have a peerless form. In the past, for a hundred kalpas, you engaged in austerities. You delight in all generosity, gentleness, and giving. You have compassion and love for all beings. I prostrate to the most compassionate one. You are always delighted by generosity and morality. Your delight in patience and diligence is utterly stable. You have the light-rays of meditation and wisdom. I prostrate to you who have peerless pristine wisdom. You overcome all incorrect assertions. Your proclamations to your retinue are like a lion’s. You are the king of healers and overcome the three stains. I prostrate to you who bring great joy. Shakyamuni, your body, speech, and mind are completely pure. Like a lotus in the mire, you are unstained by the three realms. Your speech is as melodic as Brahma’s or the call of a kalavingka. I prostrate to you who have reached the other side of the three realms. You know beings to be like magical illusions, Like watching a drama, like dreams. You know that there is no self, no person, and no life. You know all dharmas to be like mirages or moons in water. Through not knowing emptiness, peace, birthlessness, We wander in migration. With compassion and hundredfold skillful means, You establish us in the knowledge of them. You always regard beings who are tormented By hundreds of sicknesses such as desire. Sugata, you liberate hundreds of beings. You are a peerless physician. You have seen the suffering of the hundred illnesses Of birth, aging, death, the oppression of misery, Loss, and wailing with grief. Shakyamuni, you compassionately liberate us. All beings spin like a cartwheel through The migrations of animals, hungry ghosts, and hell. To the foolish, the blind, and those without protector, You show the sublime path. What you, our peerless leader, have taught Is the arya path. It was taught Throughout the past by all buddhas, The lords of Dharma, for beings’ benefit. You are gentle, soft, and supremely pleasing. You are far more delightful than even Brahma. Your speech surpasses even that of Gandharvas, kinnaras, and the greatest divine maidens. Truthful, honest, and of inexhaustible means, Your speech has innumerable qualities of training. Hearing it, hundreds of trillions of beings Are placed in the peace of the three vehicles. Those who present offerings to you gain the many pleasures Of gods and also those of human beings. They become rulers of humanity who benefit beings, Wealthy, affluent, and prosperous. Those who generate faith in you, peerless one, Become rulers of the four continents, supreme chakravartins. They inspire the ten virtuous deeds in beings. They gain the seven most precious things. The veneration of you, Buddha, Pleases the rulers of the world, Brahma and Indra, And the rulers of all the gods of Tushita, Of Others’ Emanations, and of Beyond Disputation. You dispel the many sufferings of beings. Anyone who venerates, sees, or hears you, peerless one, Will achieve the result, The ultimate state, free from aging and death. Bhagavan, you are wise in the path; you know the path. You turn this world away from the path of negativity. Bhagavan, you place beings on the arya path, Happy, peaceful, and immaculate. You treasure of merit, the merit accumulated Through your veneration will never be gone. Until their achievement of awakening, the merit of those Who venerate you will not be exhausted in millions of kalpas. They will continually experience the delight of Others’ Emanations. They will become pure and virtuous. In sublime realms, those beings will become utterly pure In body, speech, and mind. People who venerate the Buddha will attain Many qualities in this and other lives, Such as higher births, liberation, human happiness, And the treasure of all beings’ merit. Your renown and vast fame fill Hundreds of realms in all directions. The garlands of your praise, Buddha, Are continuously proclaimed in the sugatas’ assemblies. I prostrate to you, the best of human beings, Who end contagion and free beings, who are delightful to see, Who have the utmost compassion, The Bhagavan whose faculties are tranquil and who delights in peace. Having heard your speech, Buddha, may I attain The five clairvoyances and abide in space. May I become heroic and equal to the sugatas. May I bestow stainless Dharma upon beings. Through the vast merit of praising The sugata with perfect qualities, Worshipped by gods, humans, and nagas, May all beings attain buddhahood.
sems brtse ma/

d.crumb: from the Ornament of the Sutras

f.d: Praises from the Ornament of the Sutras

mdo sde rgyan las byung ba'i byams mgon gyis sangs rgyas la bstod pa ni/ sems can rnams la brtse ba can/ / phrad dang bral ba'i dgongs pa can/ / mi 'bral ba yi dgongs pa can/ / phan bde dgongs khyod la phyag 'tshal/ / thub pa sgrib kun nges par grol/ / 'jig rten thams cad zil gyis gnon/ / khyod kyi mkhyen pas shes bya khyab/ / thugs grol khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sems can dag ni thams cad kyi/ / nyon mongs ma lus thams cad 'dul/ / nyon mongs 'joms mdzad nyon mongs la/ / brtse bcas khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lhun gyis grub cing chags mi mnga'/ / thogs pa mi mnga' rtag par ni/ / mnyam par gzhag cing 'dri kun gyi/ / lan ldon khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rten dang brten pa bshad bya dang*/ / gsung dang mkhyen pa 'chad byed la/ / blo gros rtag thogs mi mnga' ba/ / legs ston khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gshegs nas spyod pa mkhyen mdzad de/ / de dag skad kyis sems can gyi/ / 'ong dang 'gro dang nges 'byung la/ / legs 'doms khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lus can kun gyis khyod mthong na/ / skyes bu dam pa lags par 'tshal/ / mthong ba tsam gyis rab dwang bar/ / mdzad pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / len dang gnas dang gtong ba dang*/ / sprul dang yongs su sgyur ba dang*/ / ting nge 'dzin dang ye shes la/ / mnga' brnyes khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thabs dang skyobs dang dag pa dang*/ / theg chen nges par 'byung ba la/ / sems can rnams la rab bslu ba'i/ / bdud 'joms khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rang gzhan don du ye shes dang*/ / spangs dang nges 'byung bgegs mdzad par/ / ston mdzad mu stegs gzhan dag gis/ / mi brdzi khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bsrung med bsnyel ba mi mnga' ba/ / 'khor gyi nang na bag brkyang gsung*/ / kun nas nyon mongs gnyis spangs pa/ / 'khor sdud khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / kun mkhyen khyod la rgyu ba dang*/ / gnas pa kun la rtag par ni/ / kun mkhyen min spyod mi mnga' ste/ / yang dag don ldan khyod phyag 'tshal/ / sems can kun gyi bya ba la/ / khyod ni dus las mi 'da' bas/ / mdzad pa rtag tu don mnga' ba/ / mi bsnyel khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'jig rten kun la nyin mtshan du/ / lan drug tu ni so sor gzigs/ / thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa/ / phan dgongs khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / spyod pa dang ni rtogs pa dang*/ / ye shes dang ni phrin las kyis/ / nyan thos rang sangs rgyas kun gyi/ / bla ma khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sku gsum dag gi byang chub che/ / rnam pa kun brnyes thams cad du/ / sems can kun gyi the tshom dag / gcod pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'dzin pa mi mnga' nyes mi mnga'/ / rnyog pa mi mnga' mi gnas pa/ / mi g.yo chos rnams thams cad la/ / spros med khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes so/ /

The praise of the Buddha by the protector Maitreya from The Ornament of the Sutras. I prostrate to you who have affection for beings, Who intend that they encounter happiness and avoid suffering, Who intend that they never be without joy, Who intend the benefit and happiness of all. You, Shakyamuni, are definitely liberated from all obscurations. You overwhelm all worlds. Your wisdom pervades all objects of knowledge. I prostrate to you, whose mind is liberated. You tame all the kleshas Of all sentient beings. You destroy kleshas yet are kind To those with kleshas. I prostrate to you. Spontaneously present, you are without Attachment or impediment And always in meditation. I prostrate to you who answer all questions. I prostrate to you who teach well, Whose intellect is always unimpeded Regarding what is to be taught—words and meaning— And the means of teaching—speech and wisdom. Coming among us, you know our conduct. I prostrate to you who clearly teach us, In our own languages, What has been, what will be, and emancipation. Any being who sees you Knows you to be a holy being. I prostrate to you, the mere sight of whom Causes great awe. I prostrate to you who have mastery Over taking birth, remaining, and letting go, And over emanation, Transformation, samadhi, and pristine wisdom. I prostrate to you who conquer The maras that deceive beings About means, refuge, purity, And the mahayana emancipation. I prostrate to you who, by demonstrating the benefit Of yourself and others through pristine wisdom, Relinquishment, emancipation, and the overcoming Of impediments, are unrivaled by tirthikas. You are beyond observance and free from forgetfulness. In assemblies, you teach at ease. You have relinquished the two aspects of affliction. I prostrate to you who gather assemblies. Omniscient one, Whether you are moving or remaining still, You are never other than omniscient. I prostrate to you who have the authentic meaning. In benefiting beings, You are never untimely. Your deeds are always meaningful. I prostrate to you who are never forgetful. You regard every world during The six periods of each day and night. You have great compassion. I prostrate to you whose intention is to bring benefit. I prostrate to you who, in your conduct, Realization, pristine wisdom, and activity, Are superior to all Shravakas and pratyekabuddhas. You attained the all-encompassing Great awakening of the trikaya. I prostrate to you who always Resolve the doubts of all beings. I prostrate to you who have no avarice, No wrongdoing, no defilements, and no indolence; You who never waver; You who are without complexity toward all dharmas.
skyes rabs phyag 'tshal/
Prostrations to the Hundred Lives
rje rang byung bas mdzad pa'i skyes rabs brgya rtsa'i sdom gyi phyag 'tshal ni/
By Lord Rangjung Dorje:

na mo shAkya mu na ye/ / stag mo shi bi ko sa la/ / tshong dpon gnyis dang ri bong dang*/ / a gas+t+ya dang sha sbyin dang*/ / thams cad sgrol dang mchod sbyin byed/ / brgya byin bram ze myos byed ma/ / legs par pha rol phyin dang nya/ / bya dang bum pa phyug po'i bu/ / dka' thub can dang tshong dpon no/ / byang chub ngang pa byang chub che/ / spre 'u ri dwags sha ra b+ha/ / ru ru sprel rgyal bzod pa smra/ / tshangs dang glang chen de dag bcu/ / zla ba lcags kyi khyim du skyes/ / ma he shing rta yi dam brtan/ / ded dpon gser mdog kun d+ha dang*/ / rigs ngan grags pa'i 'od dang bcu/ / khyim bdag sgron snang ri bong dang*/ / kun tu go byed khye 'u gnyis/ / brtan byed bde byin snyan pa'i 'od/ / chu skyes 'jig rten dga' dang bcu/ / tshangs sbyin chos tshol ye shes ldan/ / chu 'bebs dang ni me long gdong*/ / gnag lhas skyes dang gzhon nu dang*/ / rnga dang chu sreg drang srong bcu/ / snying rje can gnyis skar ma dang*/ / brgya byin bram ze gar mkhan mo/ / nga las nu dang klu yi rgyal/ / seng ge khye 'u sprin dang bcu/ / 'od ldan bram ze rgyan po pa/ / des pa dang ni glang po che/ / 'char ka nor can zla dga' dang*/ / nam mkha' dpal gyi sde dang bcu/ / snying stobs chen po zla 'od dang*/ / shi bi bram ze rtag tu brnyas/ / seng ge ded dpon nor bzang dang*/ / su sha de ba bsod nams stobs/ / 'od bzang drang srong tog gi blo/ / sngo bsangs dang ni nyi 'phreng spong*/ / rnga bong mu khyud ut+pa la/ / byang chub sems dpa' gnyis te bcu/ / 'pho dang lhums zhugs bltams pa dang*/ / bzo dang rol rtsed nges 'byung dang*/ / dka' spyad drung gshegs bdud sde bcom/ / byang chub chos 'khor mya ngan 'das/ / mdzad pa'i yon tan mthar phyin pa'i/ / rgyal ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bdag kyang khyod ltar gzhan don du/ / mdzad pa'i yon tan mthar phyin shog /

namo śhākyamunaye I prostrate to the giver to the tigress, Śhibi, Kosala, The two merchants, the rabbit, Agastya, the giver of flesh, Viśhvantara, and the offerer; Indra, the Brahmin, Unmādayantī, Supāraga, the fish, The quail, the jug, the rich man’s son, The austere one, and the merchant; Awakening, the king of swans, Mahābodhi, The monkey, the śharabha, The ruru, the monkey king, Kṣhāntivādī, Brahma, the elephant: these ten; Chandra, the renunciate in the iron building, Dhṛiṣhṭhapratijñāna, The water buffalo, the woodpecker, The captain, Suvarna, Kundha, The outcaste, and Yaśhaprabha: these ten; The householder, Lamplight, the rabbit, Samjñāpayati, the two boys, Dharitrī, Sukhaṃdatta, Pleasant Light, Padma, Lokananda: these ten; Brahmadatta, the seeker of Dharma, Jñānavatī, Jalavāhan, Ādarśhamukha, Gośhalīwarta, Kumāra, the naga king, The beaver, and the rishi: these ten; The two compassionate ones, Jyoti, Indra, the Brahmin, the dancing girl, Māndhatā, the naga king, The lion, and the boy Megha: these ten; Bhāsvara, the Brahmin, the gambler, Peśhala, the elephant, Udayanaḥ, Dhanika, Somanandī, Ākāśha, and Śhrisena: these ten; Mahāsattva, Chandraprabha, Śhivi, the Brahmin, Sadāparibhuta, The lion, the captain, Sudhana, Suśhadeva, and Puṇyabala; Suprabha, the rishi, Ketumati, Śhyāmaka, Sūryamala, The camel, Nemi, Utpala, And the two bodhisattvas: these ten. I prostrate to you, the Buddha who perfected the qualities of the twelve deeds, Who left Tushita, entered the womb, were born, Mastered crafts, disported, renounced the world, Engaged in austerities, approached the bodhi tree, Conquered the forces of Mara, attained awakening, Turned the Wheels of Dharma, and passed into nirvana. May I, like you, perfect the qualities Of these deeds for the benefit of others.

thabs mkhas thugs rjes shAkya'i rigs su 'khrungs/ / gzhan gyis mi thub bdud kyi dpung 'joms pa/ / gser gyi lhun po lta bur brjid pa'i sku/ / shAkya'i rgyal po khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gang gis dang por byang chub thugs bskyed nas/ / bsod nams ye shes tshogs gnyis rdzogs mdzad cing*/ / dus 'dir mdzad pa rgya chen 'gro ba yi/ / mgon gyur khyod la bdag gis bstod par bgyi/ / lha rnams don mdzad 'dul ba'i dus mkhyen nas/ / lha las babs nas glang chen ltar gshegs shing*/ / rigs la gzigs nas lha mo sgyu 'phrul ma'i/ / lhums su zhugs par mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zla ba bcu rdzogs shAkya'i sras po btsun mo yi/ / 'khor dang ldan mdzad thabs la mkhas pa yis/ / rgyal srid skyong bar mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'khor ba'i bya ba snying po med gzigs nas/ / khyim nas byung ste mkha' la gshegs nas kyang*/ / mchod rten rnam dag drung du nyid la nyid/ / rab tu byung bar mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / brtson pas byang chub bsgrub par dgongs nas ni/ / nai rany+dza na'i 'gram du lo drug tu/ / dka' ba spyad mdzad brtson 'grus mthar phyin pas/ / bsam gtan mchog brnyes mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thog ma med nas 'bad pa don yod phyir/ / ma ga d+ha yi byang chub shing drung du/ / skyil krung mi g.yo mngon par sangs rgyas nas/ / byang chub rdzogs par mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thugs rjes 'gro la myur du gzigs nas ni/ / wA rA Na sI la sogs gnas mchog tu/ / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor nas gdul bya rnams/ / theg pa gsum la 'god mdzad phyag 'tshal lo/ / gzhan gyi rgol ba ngan pa tshar gcod phyir/ / mu stegs ston pa drug dang lhas byin sogs/ / 'khor mo 'jig gi yul du bdud rnams btul/ / thub pa g.yul las rgyal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / srid pa gsum na dpe med yon tan gyis/ / mnyan du yod par cho 'phrul chen po bstan/ / lha mi 'gro ba kun gyis rab mchod pa/ / bstan pa rgyas par mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / le lo can rnams myur du bskul bya'i phyir/ / rtswa mchog grong gi sa gzhi gtsang ma ru/ / 'chi med rdo rje lta bu'i sku gshegs nas/ / mya ngan 'da' bar mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / yang dag nyid du 'jig pa med phyir dang*/ / ma 'ongs sems can bsod nams 'thob bya'i phyir/ / de nyid du ni ring bsrel mang sprul nas/ / sku gdung cha brgyad mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Skilled in means, from compassion you took birth as a Shakyan; You vanquished Mara’s forces while others could not. Your body resplendent as a golden Mount Meru, O King of the Shakyas, I prostrate to you. It’s you who at first roused the mind of enlightenment, Then perfected the accumulations of merit And wisdom. So vast are your deeds in this age! I praise you who are the protector of wanderers. You benefited gods, then knowing it was time To tame humans, you came down from heaven as an elephant. You looked at her caste and then entered the womb Of the Queen Mahamaya: I prostrate to this deed. When ten months had passed, you, son of the Shakyas, Were born in the auspicious grove of Lumbini. Both Brahma and Indra bowed to you with your great marks Of the family of enlightenment: I prostrate to this deed. A youth with great strength, a lion among men, You showed your great prowess at Angamagadha. You vanquished all people inflated with arrogance. You are without rival: I prostrate to this deed. In order to act in accord with the ways Of the world and avert any censure, you took A retinue of queens. Thus through means that were skillful, You governed your kingdom: I prostrate to this deed. You saw the affairs of samsara are pointless And left your household, going off in the sky. Near the Stupa of Great Purity, you by yourself Went forth to ordain: I prostrate to this deed. With the thought to accomplish enlightenment through effort, For six years you practiced austerities on the banks Of the Nairanjana and, perfecting your diligence, You gained the supreme dhyana: I prostrateto this deed. As your efforts from beginningless time had a purpose, In Magadha under the Tree of Enlightenment Unmoving you sat and manifestly awakened To perfect enlightenment: I prostrate to this deed. You soon with compassion regarded all wanderers And in Varanasi and other great places You turned the Wheel of Dharma, thus bringing your disciples Into the three vehicles: I prostrate to this deed. To vanquish the evil objections of others In the land of Varanasi, you subdued the demons— The six tirthika teachers, Devadatta, and others. The Sage triumphed in battle: I prostrate to this deed. Your qualities unparalleled in the three realms, In Shravasti you displayed wondrous miracles. All gods and humans make you great offerings. You spread the teachings: I prostrate to this deed. In order to encourage all those who are lazy To the Dharma, on Kushinagar’s good, clean ground You departed the deathless, vajralike body And passed to nirvana: I prostrate to this deed. Because in reality there is no destruction And so that the beings of the future gain merit, In that very place you left many relics— The eight parts of your remains: I prostrate to this deed.
zhes pa 'di'i thog ma'i sh+lo ka gcig pu rje 'bri gung pas mdzad par grags shing de phyin slob dpon klu sgrub kyis mdzad pa'o/
The first stanza is said to be by the Lord Drikungpa; the following stanzas were composed by Nagarjuna.

phyag 'tshal bsdus na/ ji snyed su dag phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten na/ / dus gsum gshegs pa mi yi seng ge kun/ / bdag gis ma lus de dag thams cad la/ / lus dang ngag yid dwang bas phyag bgyi 'o/ / bzang po spyod pa'i smon lam stobs dag gis/ / rgyal ba thams cad yid kyis mngon sum du/ / zhing gi rdul snyed lus rab btud pa yis/ / rgyal ba kun la rab tu phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes so/

For shortened prostrations: I prostrate to all lions among humans, As many as appear, excepting none, In the three times in worlds of ten directions Sincerely with my body, speech, and mind. With the power of this prayer for excellent conduct, I fully prostrate to all victors with As many bodies as atoms in all realms With all the victors right before my mind.
