EMAHO! How wondrous is the Buddha Infinite Light With the lord Great Compassion on his right, Great Power on his left, all in the midst Of buddhas and bodhisattvas beyond number. As soon as I pass on, may I be born Without another lifetime in between In that pure land of untold happiness And wonder that is called Sukhavati And see the Buddha Amitabha’s face. I ask all buddhas and bodhisattvas of The ten directions, bless me that my prayer Be fulfilled without any obstacles. tadyathā pañchendriya ava bodhanāye svāhā On the seventh day of the Vaisakha month of the Female Fire Bird Year, the Tulku Mingyur Dorje at the age of thirteen saw the Buddha Amitabha and his retinue, and Amitabha actually spoke these words.

phyogs dus rgyal ba sras bcas dgongs: tshogs gnyis rdzogs la rjes yi rang: bdag gi dus gsum dge bsags pa: dkon mchog gsum la mchod pa 'bul: rgyal ba'i bstan pa 'phel gyur cig: dge ba sems can kun la bsngo: 'gro kun sangs rgyas thob gyur cig: dge rtsa thams cad gcig bsdus te: bdag gi rgyud la smin gyur cig: sgrib gnyis dag nas tshogs rdzogs te: tshe ring nad med nyams rtogs 'phel: tshe 'dir sa bcu non gyur cig: nam zhig tshe 'phos gyur ma thag: bde ba can du skye gyur cig: skyes nas pad+ma'i kha phye ste: lus rten de la sangs rgyas shog: byang chub thob nas ji srid du: sprul pas 'gro ba 'dren par shog:

Consider me, buddhas and bodhisattvas Of all times and directions. I rejoice In the two accumulations, and I offer My merit of the three times to the Three Jewels. May the teachings of the Buddha flourish. I dedicate this virtue to all beings. May every being achieve buddhahood. Gathering all roots of virtue into one, May they ripen in my being. May I cleanse The two veils and perfect the accumulations, Increase my long life, health, experience, And realization, and rise through the ten levels In this life. When I pass on from this life, May I at once be born in Sukhavati. Then may the lotus open on my birth, And with that body may I gain buddhahood. Once I’ve achieved enlightenment, may I Guide beings with my emanations forever.

In the middle of a ground as even as the palm of a hand, Decorated by jewels, trees, and lakes, Is a palace made of jewels with four sides and four doors. Within it, on a lotus, sun, and moon seat, Is the protector of beings who compassionately places disciples, In this age of strive, on the path to liberation. Buddha Shakyamuni and the great arhats, I pray that you come to this place, accompanied by your entourages. All buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions, And all sanghas of shravakas from the ten directions, Whose fire of wisdom dries up the ocean of kleshas, Who are a field of liberation and merit, I invite you so that you may receive my offerings. I pray that you come, since my offerings are for beings’ benefit. The Dharma of the Lion of the Shakyas, That protector of beings, rests in your hands. All you arhats, elders, you who open The precious vessel of the Buddha’s words, I invite you in order to spread the genuine Dharma. I pray that you come, since my offerings are for beings’ benefit. As appointed by Shakyamuni, You hold the victory banner of Dharma. Angaja, Ajita, Vanavasin, Kalika, Vajriputra, Bhadra, Kanakavatsa, Kanaka Bharadhvaja, Arya Bakula, Rahula, Chudapanthaka, Pindola Bharadhvaja, Mahapanthaka, Nagasena, Gopaka, and Abheda, I pray that you come, since my offerings are for beings’ benefit. Although your perfect relinquishment and pristine wisdom are like the Buddha’s You take the form of shravakas for the sake of disciples. Your special activity is to protect the Dharma. Sixteen arhats, come here and be seated. You protect the Dharma, particularly the sugata’s words. Sixteen arhats, you have cast aside your own welfare And remain in the jungle of samsara for the benefit of others. Come here through your commitment and compassion. Upasaka who has taken refuge and listens to words of truth, And all those who serve the Three Jewels, I invite you to this garden of precious merit. I pray that you come, since my offerings are for beings’ benefit.

Peerless, the sight of you never satiates. You are beautiful and golden in color. You have one face, two hands, and are seated with crossed legs. I prostrate to you who press the earth and rest in meditation. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On great snow-covered Mount Kailash Is the arya elder Angaja, Surrounded by thirteen hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who hold an incense pot and fan. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In the crystal forest on the rishis’ mountain Is the arya elder Ajita, Surrounded by a hundred arhats. I prostrate to you whose two hands rest in meditation. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In the mountain cave of Seven Leaves Is the arya elder Vanavasin, Surrounded by fourteen hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who point a threatening forefinger and hold a fan. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On Copper Island in Jambudvipa Is the arya elder Kalika, Surrounded by eleven hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who hold golden earrings. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On the island of Singhala Is the arya elder Vajriputra, Surrounded by one thousand arhats. I prostrate to you who point a threatening forefinger and hold a fan. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On an island in the River Yamuna Is the arya elder Bhadra, Surrounded by twelve hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who teach Dharma and rest in meditation. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In the holy land of Kashmir Is the arya elder Kanakavatsa, Surrounded by five hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who hold a jeweled lasso. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In Godaniya in the west Is the arya elder Kanaka Bharadhvaja, Surrounded by seven hundred arhats. I prostrate to you whose two hands rest in meditation. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In Uttarakuru in the north Is the arya elder Bakula, Surrounded by nine hundred arhats. I prostrate to you whose left hand holds a mongoose. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On the island of Priyangku Is the arya elder Rahula, Surrounded by eleven hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who hold a precious crown. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On Vulture Peak Mountain Is the arya elder Chudapanthaka, Surrounded by sixteen hundred arhats. I prostrate to you whose two hands rest in meditation. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In Purvavideha in the east Is the arya elder Pindola Bharadhvaja, Surrounded by a thousand arhats. I prostrate to you who hold a tome and an alms bowl. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. In the abode of the thirty-three gods Is the arya elder Mahapanthaka, Surrounded by nine hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who hold a volume and teach Dharma. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On the king of mountains, Vipaliparshva, Is the arya elder Nagasena, Surrounded by twelve hundred arhats. I prostrate to you who hold a vase and a ringing staff. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On the king of mountains, Bihula, Is the arya elder Gopaka, Surrounded by fourteen hundred arhats. I prostrate to you whose two hands hold a volume. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. On the king of mountains, Himalaya, Is the arya elder Abheda, Surrounded by a thousand arhats. I prostrate to you who hold a mahabodhi stupa. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. The arya upasaka Dharmata Has his hair bound in a topknot and carries a text. In front of him is Amitabha. I prostrate to you who hold a fan and vase. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish. Armored with diligence, powerful, You protect the Buddhadharma In the east, south, west, and north. I prostrate to the four great kings. Grant your blessing so that the gurus live long And so that Dharma flourish.

Arya arhats, emanations of the Buddha, You protect the Dharma for beings’ benefit. Sixteen arhats, you are truly the Three Jewels. Grant your blessing that the Dharma long remain. Sixteen arhats, you personify compassion. Your retinues have crossed the ocean of becoming and have no kleshas. All sixteen thousand four hundred of you: Grant your blessing that the Dharma long remain. May the ocean of merit become complete, The ocean of pristine wisdom become pure, And the ocean of qualities become perfect. May we transcend all that is mundane. Through the compassion of the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the three times, You retain the appearance of shravakas and, for as long as samsara lasts, Will protect the Dharma and benefit beings. May there be the auspiciousness of the great arhats! Composed by Mahapandita Shakyashri.

las kyi sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sbyong ba zhes bya ba'i gzungs/
The Dharani that Thoroughly Purifies all Karmic Obscurations

rgya gar skad du/ Ar+yasarbakarma.AbaraNabishod+haninAmad+hAraNI/ bod skad du/ 'phags pa las kyi sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sbyong ba zhes bya ba'i gzungs/ bcom ldan 'das mi 'khrugs pa la phyag 'tshal lo/
In Sanskrit: Āryasarvakarmāvaraṇaviśodhananāmadhāraṇī In Tibetan: ’Phags pa las kyi sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sbyong ba zhes bya ba’i gzungs I prostrate to the Bhagavan Akshobhya.
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ oM kaM ka ni kaM ka ni/ ro tsa ni ro tsa ni/ tro Ta ni tro Ta ni/ trA sa ni trA sa ni/ pra ti ha na pra ti ha na/ sarba karma pa raM pa rA Ni me swAhA/

gzungs sngags 'di'i cho ga ni 'di yin te/ rtag tu bzlas brjod byas na las gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa thams cad rnam par dag par 'gyur ro/ / dus gsum du bzlas brjod byas na mtshams med pa lnga yang byang bar 'gyur ro/ / lan cig bzlas brjod byas na ltas ngan pa dang*/ rmi lam ngan pa dang bkra mi shis pa rnams med par 'gyur ro/ / lus la 'chang ngam glegs bam la bris nas mgul du thogs te 'chang na de la dus ma yin par 'chi ba rnams gtan du 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig snying rjes non te ri dwags dang bya dang mi dang mi ma yin pa rnams kyang rung ste/ 'chi ba'i rna khung du brjod na de ngan song du 'gro bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yang na shi ste dus las 'das na shi 'phos pa'i ming nas smos te de'i phyir byams pa dang snying rjes lan brgya'am stong ngam 'bum brjod na sems can de sems can dmyal bar skyes su zin kyang de'i mod la thar bar 'gyur ro/ / sa'am til lam yungs kar ram chu gang yang rung ba la bzlas brjod byas te shi ba'i lus la gtor ram/ khrus byas nas de'i 'og tu bsreg pa'am/ yang na mchod rten gyi nang du bcug ste bzhag la/ rig sngags kyang bris te mgo bo la btags na de ngan song du skyes pa yang zhag bdun gyis gdon mi za bar thar te bde 'gro mtho ris kyi 'jig rten du skye bar 'gyur ba'am/ yang na rang gi smon lam gyi dbang gis skye bar 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig zla ba nya ba'i tshe khrus byas la gtsang mar byas te dus gsum du gos brje zhing kha zas mi za ba'am yang na zas dkar bag bza' zhing sku gdung dang ldan pa'i mchod rten skor bzhin du gang gi ming dang ldan pas lan 'bum bzlas brjod byas na de ngan song nas thar te gnas gtsang ma'i lha'i ris su skyes nas sgrub pa po'i thad du 'ong ste mchod pa byed cing lus kyang ston la legs so zhes bya ba yang byin nas lan gsum bskor ba byas te mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / de'i ming bris la gzungs sngags bzlas brjod byed cing mchod rten 'bum byas la gdugs dang*/ rgyal mtshan dang*/ ba dan la sogs pas legs par mchod nas rgya mtsho chen po dang*/ yang na chu klung du btang na des sems can dmyal ba la sogs pa nas thar bar 'gyur ro/ / yang na de ltar mchod pa byas nas mjug tu lam gyi bzhi mdor mchod rten chen po byas te/ gdugs dang*/ rgyal mtshan dang*/ ba dan la sogs pas legs par mchod la 'phags pa'i dge 'dun la yang mchod rten gsol nas yon yang phul te legs par mchod nas 'di che ge mo zhig gi dge ba'i rtsa bar gyur cig / 'di kho nas bde 'gro mtho ris kyi 'jig rten du skye bar gyur cig ces kyang shes par byas na de kho na bzhin du skyes nas lus kyang ston cing legs so zhes bya ba yang byin nas mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / mtshams med pa lnga byed pa'am/ dam pa'i chos spong ba'am/ 'phags pa la skur ba btab pa yang rung ste 'chi kar rtsig pa la gzungs sngags 'di bris pa mthong na/ de'i las kyi sgrib pa thams cad zad par 'gyur na/ 'don pa dang bzlas brjod byed pa lta ci smos te/ de bzhin gshegs pa de nyid byon nas 'di skad du rigs kyi bu tshur nga'i gan du shog ces kyang gsung bar 'gyur ro/ / 'phags pa las kyi sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sbyong ba zhes bya ba'i gzungs rdzogs so/ /

This is the ritual of that dharani mantra: If you recite it continually, all the karma flowing from lifetime to lifetime will be purified. If you recite it three times daily, even the karma of the five heinous deeds will be cleared away. If you recite it once, bad signs, bad dreams, and inauspiciousness will be eliminated. If you keep it on your person or write it on a scroll and wear it around your neck, untimely death will not occur at all. If someone is filled with compassion and recites it within the hearing of a wild animal, bird, human being, or asura while they are dying, that being will not be reborn in the lower realms. Or, when someone has died, if you utter the name of the deceased and recite the dharani for them with love and compassion one hundred, one thousand or one hundred thousand times, that sentient being will instantaneously be liberated, even if they had taken rebirth in hell. If you recite it over earth, sesame seeds, mustard seeds, or water, and either sprinkle that on the body of the deceased, or wash them and then burn it under them, or place it inside a stupa, and you also write the vidya mantra and affix it to their head, then even if they are born in the lower realms, within seven days they will definitely be liberated and reborn in a higher rebirth or according to their own aspirations. If, on the full moon, someone bathes and cleans, changes their clothes three times daily, either fasts or eats just a small amount of vegetarian food, and recites it a hundred thousand times while circumambulating a stupa that contains body relics, then that person whose name they have with them will be freed from the lower realms and take rebirth in a pure deva realm. That person will then come directly to the practitioner, make offerings and appear physically. They will say, “Well done,” circumambulate three times, and disappear. If you write their name, recite the dharani mantra and make a hundred thousand stupas, and offer parasols, victory banners, pendants, and so on to the stupas and then cast them into the ocean or a river, through that, that person will be freed from the hells or other such realms. Or, if you make offerings in that way and then afterwards erect a large stupa at a crossroads, venerate it well with parasols, victory banners, pendants, and so on, offer that stupa to the noble sangha and also make donations, and then declare, “May this become so-and-so’s root of virtue. May this very person be born in the higher realms,” they will be born in that very way, appear physically, say, “Well done,” and then disappear. If someone who has committed the five heinous deeds, rejected the true Dharma, or disparaged a noble being sees this dharani mantra written on a wall as they are dying, all their karmic obscurations will be extinguished. Thus there is no need to mention their uttering or reciting it— The Tathagata himself will arrive and say, “Child of good family, come here to me.” This completes The Dharani that Thoroughly Purifies all Karmic Obscurations.
sdug bsngal las rnam par dgrol ba'i gzungs kyi mdo/
The Sutra of the Dharani that Thoroughly Liberates from Suffering

rgya nag skad du/ pa ci khu'u nan thu'o lu'o nyi cing*/ bod skad du/ sdug bsngal las rnam par dgrol ba'i gzungs kyi mdo/ bcom ldan 'das mgon po mi 'khrugs pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na/ rgyal bu rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na/ nyan thos dang*/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po grangs med pa dag dang thabs cig tu bzhugs te/ lha dang mi dang lha ma yin sogs kyi 'dus pa chen po tshad med pas kyang yongs su bskor ba'o/ / de'i tshe 'dus pa de dag gi dbus na byang chub sems dpa' brjod du med pa'i yon tan gyi rgyan zhes bya ba zhig mchis pa de stan las langs te bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs la mgo bos phyag btsal te/ thal mo sbyar te bkur sti dang bcas pas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das/ deng 'dir 'jig rten gyi khams su sems can tshad med pa dag nyon mongs pa'i rgyu dang rkyen gyi dbang gis sdig pa'i las sna tshogs pa mngon par 'du byed pas/ sems can dmyal ba dang*/ yi dwags dang*/ byol song rnams su ltung bar 'gyur ba'am/ yang na lha dang mi'i 'gro ba dag tu sdug bsngal dos drag pa sna tshogs pa myong bar 'gyur ba la thugs brtse bas rnam par dgrol ba'i thabs bstan par mdzad du gsol/ de skad ces gsol pa dang*/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rigs kyi bu/ legs so/ /legs so/ / khyod kyis sems can thams cad la snying brtse bas de ltar gsol ba btab pa legs so/ / don de'i phyir deng khyod la sdug bsngal thams cad las rnam par dgrol ba'i thabs bsdus pa ngas bshad kyis/ nyon cig yang dag par nyon cig / rigs kyi bu/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mi 'khrugs pa zhes bya bas/ sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde ba'i don 'tshal bas na/ gzungs sngags 'di gsungs shing 'dus pa rnams la bzlas brjod du bgyid par gnang ngo*/ / sngags smras pa/ kaMkani kaMkani/ rotsani rotsani/ troTani troTani/ trAsani trAsani/ pratihan pratihan/ sarba karma paraMparANi me swAhA/ rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis/ de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas mi 'khrugs pa la g.yo dang sgyu ma mchis par phyag byas te gzungs 'di 'chang ba dang 'dzin par byas na/ sngon spyad pa'i mtshams med pa'i las lnga po dag gam/ rtsa ba bzhi'am/ mi dge ba bcu'am/ 'phags pa'i tshogs la skur ba btab pa'am/ dam pa'i chos la skur ba btab pa'i nyes pa dang bcas pa thams cad rab tu zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / 'chi ba'i dus la bab pa'i tshe na/ bcom ldan 'das mi 'khrugs pa de dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams gang gi mdun na mngon sum du 'ongs nas/ snyan par brjod cing mgu bar byas te gang de rab tu dga' bar byed do/ / de nas deng khyod bsu bar byed kyis bdag gang du gnas pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing du lhan cig tu 'dong bar rigs so zhes gsungs par 'gyur ro/ / shi 'phos nas kyang nges par de bzhin gshegs pa mi 'khrugs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnam par dag par skye bar 'gyur ro/ / rigs kyi bu/ gzhan yang de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas ngan song sbyong ba'i rgyal po zhes bya bas/ sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde ba'i don 'tshal bas na/ gzungs sngags 'di gsungs shing 'dus pa rnams la bzlas brjod du bgyid par gnang ngo*/ / sngags smras pa/ shod+hane shod+hane sarba pApaM bishod+hane shud+d+he bishud+d+he sarba karma bishud+d+he swAhA/ gal te rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis/ de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas ngan song sbyong ba'i rgyal po la g.yo dang sgyu ma mchis par phyag byas te sngags 'di 'chang ba dang 'dzin par byas na/ bskal pa khri bzhi stong gi sngon gyi tshe rabs kyang rtag tu dran par 'gyur ro/ / gang du skye ba'i gnas su skyes pa'i lus 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / dbang po phun sum tshogs shing las 'bras la mngon par yid ches par 'gyur ro/ / bzo yi rigs sna tshogs la mkhas shing bstan bcos thams cad legs par shes par 'gyur ro/ / gtong ba la spro zhing 'dod pa thams cad la yid 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / sdig pa'i las mi bgyi zhing 'jigs pa thams cad dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / yang dag pa'i 'tsho ba dang shes rab ldan zhing skye dgu kun gyis shin tu gces par 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi drung du dam pa'i chos rgyun mar thos par 'gyur ro/ / byang chub 'dod pa'i sems thang cig tsam yang spong bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yon tan thams cad kyis bdag nyid mdzes par 'gyur ro/ / yang dag pa'i sdom pa dang ldan zhing sdig pa'i las thams cad la 'jigs par 'gyur ro/ / gtan du nyon mongs pa med cing mnyen zhing rab tu zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / lha dang mi dag gi nang du rtag tu bde ba myong bar 'gyur ro/ / bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub myur du 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / pha rol tu phyin pa bcu po dag las phyir ldog par mi 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu sems can ma lus pa phan bde la 'god par 'dod par 'gyur ro/ / gang nyams su blangs pa thams cad bdag don du gzhol bar mi 'gyur ro/ / gang du skye ba'i gnas su rtag tu sangs rgyas mthong ba 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / dam pa'i chos skyong ba'i 'phags pa'i tshogs kyi grangs su bgrang bar 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis de skad ces bka' stsal nas/ nyan thos dang byang chub sems dpa' dang lha dang mi dang lha ma yin gyi tshogs dang bcas pa yi rangs te/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa la mngon par bstod do/ / sdug bsngal las rnam par dgrol ba'i gzungs rdzogs so/ /

In Chinese: Pa chi khu’u nan tuo luo nyi ching In Tibetan: sDug bsngal las rnam par dgrol ba’i gzungs kyi mdo I prostrate to the Bhagavan Buddha, Protector Akshobhya. Thus have I heard. At one time, the Bhagavan was dwelling in Shravasti, in Jetavana Grove, the park of Anathapindada, together with countless hearer disciples and bodhisattva mahasattvas, and also surrounded by an immeasurable, great assembly of gods, humans, asuras, and so on. At that time, amidst those assembled was the bodhisattva named Ornament of Inexpressible Qualities, who arose from his seat and prostrated with his head at the feet of the Bhagavan. With palms together and with respect, he said to the Bhagavan, “Bhagavan, at present in this world system boundless sentient beings are engaging in various sorts of wrongdoing under the influence of the causes and conditions of kleshas, and thus will fall into hell, preta, or animal realms, or else will experience the various severe forms of suffering of god and human rebirths. I request you to teach a method to thoroughly liberate them, out of compassion and affection.” He said this, and the Bhagavan replied, “Child of noble family, excellent. Excellent. It is excellent that you have made such a request, out of compassion and affection for sentient beings. To that end, I will now teach you a method that thoroughly liberates from all suffering, therefore listen. Listen well. Child of noble family, because the completely perfect buddha named Bhagavan Akshobhya seeks benefit and happiness for all sentient beings, he uttered this dharani mantra, and had those assembled recite it. The mantra is spoken thus: kaṃkani kaṃkani rochani rochani troṭani troṭani trāsani trāsani pratihana pratihana sarva karma paramparāṇi me svāhā Any son or daughter of noble family who without pretense or guile pays homage to the tathagata, the completely perfect buddha Akshobhya, and upholds and memorizes this dharani will perfectly pacify all the wrongs they have previously done, including the five heinous deeds, the four root downfalls, the ten non-virtues, disparaging the assembly of noble ones, or disparaging the true Dharma. When their moment of death arrives, Bhagavan Akshobhya and the bodhisattvas will come directly before them, speak pleasantly and gladden them, and will make them thoroughly joyful. They will then say, ‘We welcome you now, thus it is right that we go together to the buddha field we dwell in.’ After dying too, that person will definitely be reborn in the pure land of Tathagata Akshobhya. Moreover, child of the lineage, since the tathagata, the completely perfect Buddha Durgati Shodhana Raja seeks benefit and happiness for all sentient beings, he uttered this dharani mantra and had those assembled recite it. The mantra is spoken thus: śhodhane śhodhane sarva pāpam viśhodhane śhuddhe viśhuddhe sarva karma viśhuddhe svāhā If any son of the lineage or daughter of the lineage pays homage without pretense or guile to the tathagata, the completely perfect Buddha Durgati Shodhana Raja, and upholds and memorizes this mantra, they will always remember their lives from the previous fourteen thousand aeons. Wherever they are born, they will always attain a powerful body. They will have perfect faculties, and have firm conviction in cause and effect. They will be skilled in the various crafts, and will understand all the commentarial treatises well. They will delight in giving, and will be repulsed by all objects of desire. They will engage in no wrong acts and be free of all fear. They will have a right livelihood and wisdom, and all beings will be extremely fond of them. They will always hear the true Dharma in the presence of a spiritual friend, unceasingly. They will not abandon their wish for enlightenment even for an instant. They themselves will be beautified by all good qualities. They will be endowed with perfect restraint, and will fear all wrongdoing. They will always be without kleshas, and be mild and thoroughly pacified. They will always experience happiness among gods and humans. They will quickly attain the unsurpassed state of complete and perfect enlightenment. They will never turn away from the ten transcendences. They will always have the wish to bring about the benefit and happiness of all sentient beings without exception. Whatever they practice, they will not engage in self-interest. Wherever they are born, they will always be able to see a buddha. They will be counted among the noble community that protects the true Dharma.” After the Bhagavan had spoken thus, the community of hearer disciples, bodhisattvas, gods, humans, and asuras rejoiced and praised what the Bhagavan had said. The Sutra of the Dharani that Thoroughly Liberates from Suffering is completed.

chen po thang gur gyi sde snod gsum pa zhon tsang nas gong ma'i bka' lung gis rgya nag gi skad du bsgyur ba las snyigs ma'i dus su byang phyogs gangs can gyi rgyud du byung ba zhwa mthon mthing can o rgyan phrin las dbang gi rdo rjes bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa'o/ / shing pho rta lo spyi lo _2014_lor slar zhus so/ /

Translated into Chinese by Hsuan Tsang, the Tripitaka Master of the Great Tang, by imperial edict, and from that, translated and finalized by the holder of the Black Hat, Ogyen Trinley Wang gi Dorje, who was born in the lineage of the northern snowy land in degenerate times. Translation revised in the Wood Horse Year, 2014.
[sman bla]
Offerings to the Medicine Buddha
de bzhin gshegs pa bdun mchod pa'i cho ga bsdus te bya ba bzhugs so/ /
A Concise Ritual of Offering to the Seven Tathagatas

bcom ldan 'das sman gyi bla baiDUr+ya'i 'od kyi rgyal po la sogs pa de bzhin gshegs pa bdun la phyag 'tshal lo/ /de bzhin gshegs pa bdun mchod pa'i cho ga bsdus te bya bar 'dod pas/ so sor thar pa'i sdom pa gang rung dang ldan zhing byang chub tu sems bskyed la/ dus tshes brgyad lta bu'am/ rgyun du gnas na yid du 'ong ba gtsang mar byas pa'i gnas su maN+Dal me tog gi tshom bu lha grangs dang mnyam pa bkod/ sku gsung thugs kyi rten ci rigs su bzhugs/ mchod pa ci 'byor yang bshams te nus pa ma sris par bshams/ de nas khrus byas te stan bde bar 'dug la stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin ci rigs su bsgom/

I prostrate to Medicine Buddha, the King of Vaidurya Light, and the rest of the Seven Tathagatas. Those who wish to practice this concise offering ritual to the Seven Tathagatas should be holding any of the pratimoksha vows, and generate bodhichitta. Either on a date such as the eighth of the month or as a regular practice, prepare as many mandala and flower arrangements as there are deities, in a place that has been made pleasant and clean. Set up symbols of body, speech, and mind of any type, and arrange whatever offerings you can afford. Set out whatever you are able. After that, wash yourself, sit comfortably and engage in any type of meditative concentration on emptiness.

gang gis rten cing 'brel bar 'byung*/ / 'gag pa med pa skye med pa/ / chad pa med pa rtag med pa/ / 'ong ba med pa 'gro med pa/ / tha dad don min don gcig min/ / spros pa nyer zhi zhir bstan pa/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas smra rnams kyi/ / dam pa de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes dang*/

I prostrate to the Perfect Buddha, Best among speakers, who taught that Whatever arises interdependently Has no cessation and no arising, No annihilation and no permanence, No coming and no going, Is neither different nor the same, And is free of elaborations. And:

gang zhig rkyen las skyes pa de ma skyes/ / de la skye ba'i rang bzhin yod ma yin/ / rkyen la rag las gang de stong pa ste/ / gang gis stong nyid shes de bag yod yin/ zhes pa ngag don dran bzhin du brjod/
Whatever is born of conditions is unborn. It does not have birth as its nature. Whatever is subject to conditions is empty. Whoever understands emptiness is alert. Recite while recalling the meaning.

de las langs nas/ sems can thams cad bde ba dang bde ba'i rgyu dang ldan par gyur cig / sdug bsngal dang sdug bsngal gyi rgyu dang bral bar gyur cig / sdug bsngal med pa'i bde ba dam pa dang mi 'bral bar gyur cig / nye ring chags sdang gnyis dang bral ba'i btang snyoms chen po la gnas par gyur cig / lan gsum mthar tshad med bzhi bsgom zhing*/

Then arise from that, and meditate on the four boundless thoughts: May all sentient beings have happiness and the causes of happiness. May they be free of suffering and the causes of suffering. May they not be parted from supreme joy that is without sorrow. May they abide in great equanimity, free of attachment or hatred for those near or far. Recite three times.
sangs rgyas chos dang tshogs kyi mchog rnams la/ / byang chub bar du bdag ni skyabs su mchi/ / bdag gis sbyin sogs bgyis pa 'di dag gis/ / 'gro la phan phyir sangs rgyas 'grub par shog /
Until enlightenment, I go for refuge To the Buddha, Dharma, and the supreme Sangha By acting generously and so forth, May I become a buddha to help beings.
de nas rang gi nus pa dang phyogs bcu'i de bzhin gshegs pa sras dang bcas pas de ltar byin gyis brlabs par yang bsam/
After that, also think that your own potential and the tathagatas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions confer blessings for this to come about. Then repeat three times:

dkon mchog gsum gyi bden pa dang*/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi mthu dang*/ tshogs gnyis yongs su rdzogs pa'i mnga' thang chen po dang*/ chos kyi dbyings rang bzhin rnam par dag cing bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i stobs kyis/ yul phyogs 'di thams cad zhing khams rnam par dag pa 'jig rten gyi khams bde ba can lta bu yon tan bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang ldan par gyur cig / gzhal med khang chen po rgyu rin po che sna tshogs las grub pa/ rgya stong gsum gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma dang mnyam pa/ rnam par thar pa'i sgo bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang ldan pa 'od zer chen po rab tu 'bar ba/ sems can thams cad kyi don thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ gdan rin po che seng ge'i khri pad+ma dang zla ba dpag tu med pa dang*/ mchod pa'i sprin bzang por spyod pa'i smon lam las byung ba bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang ldan par gyur cig / ces lan gsum bzlas/

Through the power of the truth of the Three Jewels and the power of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, through the great might of the completion of the two accumulations, and through the force of the naturally pure and inconceivable dharmadhatu, may this entire area become a pure land like the realm of Sukhavati, replete with inconceivable good qualities. May this become a great palace made of the seven precious substances, vast as a billion worlds equaling the grains of sand in the Ganges, possessing the inconceivable gateway to complete liberation. May it blaze tremendously with great rays of light, completing all the aims of all sentient beings, and may it be provided with countless precious seats, lion thrones with lotus and moon, and inconceivable clouds of offerings arising from the Aspiration for Excellent Conduct.

dkon mchog gsum gyi bden pa dang*/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi byin gyis brlabs pa dang*/ tshogs gnyis yongs su rdzogs pa'i mnga' thang chen po dang*/ chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag cing bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i stobs kyis de bzhin du gyur cig / lan gsum bzlas la/

Then recite three times: Through the power of the truth of the Three Jewels, through the blessings of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, through the great might of the completion of the two accumulations, and through the force of the pure and inconceivable dharmadhatu, may it become just so.

de nas 'phags pa spyan drangs te/ /pus mo btsugs te me tog blangs/ thal mo sbyar nas 'di skad ces/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan legs par yongs bsgrags dpal gyi rgyal po dang*/ de bzhin gshegs pa rin po che dang zla ba dang pad+mas rab tu brgyan pa mkhas pa gzi brjid sgra dbyangs kyi rgyal po dang*/ de bzhin gshegs pa gser bzang dri med rin chen snang ba brtul zhugs grub pa dang*/ de bzhin gshegs pa mya ngan med mchog dpal dang*/ de bzhin gshegs pa chos bsgrags rgya mtsho'i dbyangs dang*/ de bzhin gshegs pa chos kyi rgya mtsho mchog gi blos rnam par rol pa mngon par mkhyen pa dang*/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo bsgyur ba/ bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas sman gyi bla baiDUr+ya'i 'od kyi rgyal po dang*/ da ltar bdag cag gi ston pa bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa 'dzam bu'i gling 'dir mya ngan las 'das pa'i tshul bstan kyang*/ zhing khams gzhan du de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par rol pa sna tshogs kyis 'gro ba'i don mdzad cing bzhugs pa dang*/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa dang*/ rgyal ba'i sras skyabs grol dang*/ phyag na rdo rje la sogs pa dpag tu med pa dang*/ dam pa'i chos dang 'khor rnam bzhi skyong bar zhal gyis bzhes pa lha'i dbang po brgya byin dang*/ tshangs pa dang*/ rgyal po chen po bzhi dang*/ gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon chen po ji 'jigs la sogs pa gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon thams cad la yang sngon gyi thugs dam bzang po las gleng ste/ bdag cag la sogs pa 'gro ba mang po skyob pa'i slad du mgon skyabs dpung gnyen du spyan 'dren zhing mchis na mchod pa'i tshogs sbyar ba'i pho brang gi dkyil 'khor 'dir gshegs shing gdan 'dzoms pa chen po mdzad de byin gyis brlabs par ci gnang*/ / lan gcig bzlas/

ma lus sems can kun gyi mgon gyur cing*/ / bdud sde dpung bcas mi bzad 'joms mdzad lha/ / dngos rnams ma lus ji bzhin mkhyen gyur pa'i/ / bcom ldan 'khor dang bcas te gshegs su gsol/ / bcom ldan bskal pa grangs med du ma ru/ / 'gro la brtse phyir thugs rje rnam sbyangs shing*/ / smon lam rgya chen dgongs pa yongs rdzogs pa'i/ / khyod bzhed 'gro don mdzad dus 'di lags na/ / de phyir chos dbyings pho brang lhun grub nas/ / rdzu 'phrul byin rlabs sna tshogs ston mdzad cing*/ / mtha' yas sems can tshogs rnams sgrol ba'i phyir/ / yongs dag 'khor dang bcas te gshegs su gsol/ / bcom ldan 'dir ni byon pa legs/ / bdag cag bsod nams skal par ldan/ / bdag gi mchod yon bzhes slad du/ / 'di nyid du ni bzhugs su gsol/ / stong gsum kun dang mnyam pa yi/ / pad+ma 'dab brgyad ge sar bcas/ / bde zhing yangs par 'bul lags na/ / ci bde bar ni bzhugs su gsol/ /

For each and every being, a protector, You vanquished the ferocious hordes of Mara. You know all things just as they are, Bhagavan: We pray you come here with your retinue. Bhagavan, for many countless aeons you Trained in compassion out of love for beings: Now is the time to fulfill your vast aspirations By benefitting beings as you wished. Thus we pray that out of the spontaneous palace Of the dharmadhatu, you and your pure retinue Will come, displaying miracles and blessings, To liberate infinite sentient beings. The Bhagavan is welcome here! We have such merit and good fortune. In order to accept our offerings, We ask that you remain right here. We offer you this eight-petaled lotus, Spacious and comfortable, equal in size To this realm of a billion worlds. We pray you take your seat with ease.

spyan drangs pa'i rjes/ so so'i zhing khams nas rdzu 'phrul gyis nam mkha' la gshegs te gzhal med khang gi dbus su seng ge'i khri chen po brgyad la de bzhin gshegs pa brgyad bzhugs/ chos po ti yang bzhugs/ bar gyi snam bu la byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la sogs pa dpag tu med pa bzhugs/ gsum pa la g.yas gral du tshangs pa dang brgya byin/ g.yon gral du gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon bcu gnyis/ sgo bzhi la rgyal po chen po bzhi rang rang gis dam bcas pa bzhin du sgrub cing bzhugs par gyur par bsam la/

After they have been invited, think: Each of the eight tathagatas comes through the sky as an emanation from their own pure realm to sit upon eight great lion thrones in the middle of the palace, and there are also Dharma texts set up there. At the intermediate wall are seated bodhisattva Manjushri and countless other bodhisattvas. In the third place, in the row of seats on the right are Brahma and Indra, and on the left the twelve yaksha generals. The Four Great Kings are seated at the four gates and each is acting as he had pledged.

de ltar bsam pa'i rjes la/ khrus gsol rgyas pa phyag len ltar dang maN+Dal rgyas par 'bul/ smon thun 'don srol gda'ang rgyun du bsdus pa 'di tsam gyis 'thus te/ khrus kyi khang pa shin tu dri zhim par/ / shel gyi sa gzhi gsal zhing 'tsher ba bstar/ / rin chen 'bar ba'i ka ba yid 'ong ldan/ / mu tig 'od chags bla res bres pa der/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams dang de sras la/ / rin chen bum pa mang po spos kyi chu/ / yid 'ong legs par bkang ba glu dang ni/ / rol mor bcas pa du mas sku khrus gsol/ /

After contemplating thus, offer an ablution as in the extensive practice, and make an extensive mandala offering. Either in the present custom of brief aspiration recitations, or as a daily practice, this condensed version alone is sufficient: Within this sweetly fragrant house for bathing, Where the bright and lustrous floors are paved with crystal, Alluring pillars are aglow with jewels, And glistening pearls are draped in canopies, I bathe the sugatas and bodhisattvas From precious vases that have been filled full Of water imbued with many fragrances, Accompanied by song and instruments.
oM sarba ta thA ga ta a b+hi She ka te sa ma ya shrI ye hU~M/
oṃ sarva tathāgata abhiṣhekate samaya śhrīye huṃ

ji ltar bltams pa tsam gyis ni/ / lha rnams kyis ni khrus gsol ltar/ / lha yi chu ni dag pa yis/ / de bzhin bdag gis sku khrus gsol/ / 'di ni khrus mchog dpal dang ldan/ / thugs rje'i chu ni bla na med/ / byin rlabs ye shes chu yin te/ / ci 'dod dngos grub stsol bar mdzod/ / de dag sku la mtshungs pa med pa'i gos/ / gtsang la dri rab bgos pas sku phyi'o/ / srab 'jam yang pa lha yi gos/ / mi bskyod rdo rje'i sku brnyes la/ / mi phyed dad pas bdag 'bul na/ / bdag sogs rdo rje'i sku thob shog / lhag bsam dag pa'i na bza' 'di 'bul bas/ / lus la ngur smrig gos gyon sems la ni/ / ngo tsha khrel yod bzod pa'i gos gyon nas/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la mchod par bgyi/ / sna tshogs dbang po'i gzhu ltar rab bkra zhing*/ / gang la reg na bde ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i/ / gos bzang rin chen bdag blo sbyong phyir 'bul/ / bzod pa dam pa'i gos kyis brgyan par shog / brjod la/

Just as the gods offered ablution To the Buddha when he was born, In the same way we offer ablution With the pure water of the gods. This is the glorious, supreme ablution. It is the most sublime water of compassion, The water of your blessings and of your wisdom. We pray you grant whatever siddhis we seek. With cloths that are beyond compare and clean, Infused with a fine scent, I dry their bodies. By offering fine, soft divine cloth With unwavering faith in those who have Attained indestructible vajra bodies May we too attain vajra bodies. By offering this cloth that is our pure intent, As the body is attired in saffron robes, So we clothe our mind in modesty and patience, And venerate the mother who gave birth to the Buddha. Of many colors, exquisite as a rainbow, A delight to just touch: to cleanse our mind We offer this excellent precious cloth. May we be adorned by the finest cloth, patience.

maN+Dal rgyas pa 'bul/ sa gzhi spos chus byugs shing me tog bkram/ / ri rab gling bzhi nyi zlas brgyan pa 'di/ / sangs rgyas zhing du dmigs te phul ba yis/ / 'gro kun rnam dag zhing der spyod par shog / mnyes byed maN+Dal bzang po 'di phul bas/ / byang chub lam la bar chad mi 'byung zhing*/ / dus gsum bde gshegs dgongs pa rtogs pa dang*/ / srid par mi 'khrul zhi bar mi gnas shing*/ / nam mkha' mnyam pa'i 'gro rnams sgrol bar shog / phyag 'tshal ba dang mchod cing bshags pa dang*/ / rjes su yi rang bskul zhing gsol ba yi/ / dge ba cung zad bdag gis ci bsags pa/ / thams cad bdag gis byang chub phyir bsngo_'o/ /

Make a long mandala offering: This earth, perfumed with scented water, strewn with flowers, Graced with Mount Meru, the four lands, the sun and moon, I visualize to be a buddha realm and offer So that all beings enjoy a perfectly pure realm. By offering this excellent mandala that brings delight, May no obstacles arise on our path to enlightenment. May we realize what is known by the sugatas of the three times. Not wandering lost in samsara, nor resting in nirvana’s peace, May we liberate all beings throughout the reaches of space. We dedicate to enlightenment whatever Slight merit we have gathered from prostrating, Offering, confessing, rejoicing, Requesting, and making supplications.

yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bdun gyis thabs mkhas pa dang*/ sngon gyi smon lam gyi khyad par rgyas pa rlabs po che dag ji ltar btab cing byin gyis brlabs pa dang*/ don de nyid da ltar bdag cag gi ston pa bcom ldan 'das dpal shAkya thub pas ji ltar bka' stsal cing byin gyis brlabs pa dang*/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal dang*/ skyabs grol dang*/ phyag na rdo rje la sogs pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis ji ltar byin gyis brlabs pa dang*/ tshangs pa dang lha'i dbang po brgya byin dang*/ rgyal po chen po bzhi dang*/ gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon chen po bcu gnyis la sogs pa dam pa'i chos skyong ba'i dge bsnyen chen po rnams dang*/ thams cad gdan 'dzoms pa'i spyan sngar pho brang gi dkyil 'khor bshams/ 'byor pa'i stobs ci mchis pas mchod pa'i tshogs sbyar nas mtshan nas brjod de mchod pa 'bul/ bka' drin nod cing mchis na/ gdan 'dzoms pas sngon ji ltar byin gyis brlabs shing bka' stsal pa bzhin du mdo sde'i phan yon ji skad 'byung ba'i bka' drin thams cad/ che ge mo'am/ bdag cag la sogs sems can thams cad kyis 'phral du thob par byin gyis brlab par mdzad du gsol/ gong gi phyogs bcu dus gsum gyi sogs nas 'di bar lan gsum bzlas/

Repeat the following three times: We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the tathagatas of the ten directions and the three times, and to the bodhisattvas. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha King of Glorious Well-Renowned Name. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha King of Majestic Melodious Sound, Skilled and Adorned with Jewels, Moon and Lotus. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha Excellent Golden Flawless Jeweled Appearance Whose Vows are Accomplished. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha Glorious Supreme Sorrow-less One. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha Voice of an Ocean of Proclaimed Dharma. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha Mind that is a Supreme Ocean of Dharma Directly Knowing the Playful Display. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Medicine Buddha King of Vaidurya Light. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Teacher, the Bhagavan Tathagata Arhat Completely Perfect Buddha, the Victorious Shakyamuni. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge To all the Jewels of the pure Dharma, The supreme lamps to dispel the darkness of ignorance, The best medicine to cure the disease of suffering. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the bodhisattva mahasattva Youthful Manjushri. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the bodhisattva mahasattva Noble Kyabdrol. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the Glorious Vajrapani, and the rest of the bodhisattva mahasattvas. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to Brahma, Indra, the Four Great Kings, and the rest of the Dharma protectors. We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to Kumbhira and the rest of the twelve great yaksha generals, each with their seven hundred thousand servants. We make offerings and venerate all these assemblies of noble ones, with these actual offering objects, such as oil for anointing, flowers, incense, lamps, food, music, cymbals, parasols, and banners, as well as everything excellent in the ten directions that gives delight and is not claimed by any owner, made of the very best of celestial and human materials. We fill all the endless skies with oceans of clouds of offerings arising from the Aspiration for Excellent Conduct, produced by dharani, the power of the mind, and the strength of our aspirations, and these we offer. We fully confess all the unvirtuous misdeeds we have committed in all our lifetimes, while cycling through samsara since beginningless time: in short, doing what ought not to be done and not doing what ought to be done, and all the misdeeds we ourselves have committed. We rejoice in all the merit produced by all the virtuous acts done in the three times by the noble ones and by ordinary beings. We exhort all the conquerors in the ten directions to turn the unsurpassable wheel of Dharma. We beseech all those lamps of the world wishing to display the deed of passing into nirvana to engage in deeds benefitting the world without passing into nirvana, and to remain long. Great gathering of bhagavans, please consider us. Bhagavans of great compassion, in the latter times, during the final five hundred-year period when there arise false imitations of the pure Dharma please care for all us sentient beings who are enshrouded in various karmic veils, afflicted with various illnesses, tormented by grief and suffering of various sorts, and poverty-stricken. For the welfare, benefit, and happiness of gods and humans, through the skill in means of the seven bhagavan, tathagata, arhat, completely perfect buddhas of the past, and the blessings granted for the especially expansive and vast aspirations made in the past; and just as now our teacher, the Glorious Bhagavan Shakyamuni declared and granted blessings for this very purpose; and just as Noble Manjushri, Kyabdrol, Vajrapani and the rest of the bodhisattva mahasattvas granted blessings; and Brahma, Indra the Lord of the Gods, the Four Great Kings, the twelve great yaksha generals and the rest of the great upasaka Dharma protectors have all gathered together, and the mandala of the palace has been established before them; we have arranged this collection of offerings according to our resources and uttered their names, and we make offerings: May this gathering kindly accept: Please grant your blessings so that we or so-and-so and all other sentient beings immediately attain all that you have granted blessings for and declared in the past, and all the future kindness of the benefits of the sutras as stated. Repeat the above from “We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge to the tathagatas of the ten directions and the three times, together with the bodhisattvas” to here three times.
skabs 'dir gzungs sngags bzlas/
Next recite the dharani mantra either 108, 21 or 7 times in each practice session, as appropriate to the time and circumstance:

tad+yathA/ g+hu me g+hu me/ i mi ne/ mi hi/ ma ti ma ti/ sap+ta ta thA ga ta/ sa mA d+h+ya d+hiSh+Thi te/ a te ma te/ pA le pA paM sho d+ha ni/ sarba pA paM nA sha ya/ ma ma bud+d+he bud+d+hot+ta me/ u me ku me/ bud+d+ha k+She tra pa ri sho d+ha ni/ d+ha me ni d+ha me/ me ru me ru/ me ru shi kha re/ sarba a kA la mra t+yunI/pA ra Ni/ bud+d+he su bud+d+he/ bud+d+ha a d+hiSh+Thi te na/ rak+Shan+tu me/ sarba de bA_sa me a sa me/ sa ma n+wA ha ran+tu me/ sarba bud+d+ha/ bo d+hi satwA/ sha me sha me/ pra sha man+tu me/ sarba I t+yud pa dra ba byA d+ha yaH pU ra Ni pU ra Ni pU ra ya me/ sarba A sha yA bai DUr+ya pra ti b+hA se/ sarba pA paM k+Sha yaM kA ri swA hA/

tadyathā ghu me ghu me i mi ne mihi mati mati sapta tathāgata samādhy adhiṣhṭhite ate mate pāle pāpaṃ śhodhani sarva pāpaṃ nāśhaya mama buddhe buddhottame ume kume buddha kṣhetra pariśhodhani dhameni dhame meru meru meru śhikhare sarva akāla mṛityunī pāraṇi buddhe subuddhe buddha adhiṣhṭhitena rakṣhantu me sarva devāḥ same asame samanvāharantu me sarva buddha bodhisatvā śha me śha me praśhamantu me sarva ītyudapa drava vyādhayaḥ pūraṇi pūraṇi pūra yame sarva āśhayā vaiḍūrya pratibhāse arva pāpaṃ kṣhayaṃ kāri svāhā
zhes cho ga tshar re la brgya rtsa brgyad dam/ nyi shu rtsa gcig gam/ bdun re gang 'os long skabs dang bstun te/ de nas/
Then:

bla ma mnyam med sangs rgyas rin po che/ / dus gsum bde gshegs sras bcas thams cad kyis/ / sku gsung thugs kyi ngo bor byin brlabs pa/ / bka' drin chen po'i zhabs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ma bcos spros bral bla ma chos kyi sku/ / bde chen longs spyod bla ma chos kyi rje/ / pad sdong las 'khrungs bla ma sprul pa'i sku/ / sku gsum rdo rje 'chang la phyag 'tshal lo/ / za hor rgyal po'i rigs 'khrungs dge slong gang*/ / mkhan po byang chub sems dpa' zhi ba 'tsho/ / sdom brtson rig pa'i gnas lnga kun la mkhas/ / bslab pa gsum ldan de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'phags mchog rigs gsum mgon po bsam bzhin du/ / bod 'bangs chos la 'khod phyir skur sprul pa/ / mnga' bdag srong btsan khri srong ral pa can/ / chos rgyal mes dbon rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dga' ldan gnas na nam mkha' dri ma med/ / 'phags pa'i gnas na dI paM ka ra zhes/ / kha ba can na dpal ldan a ti sha/ / sa steng grags pas khyab la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ma 'ongs sangs rgyas bdun pa rab gsal gang*/ / sgrol mas rjes bzung mkhas shing grub pa brnyes/ / shAkya shrI b+ha dra zhes grags pa'i/ / kha che mkhas pa de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mkhyen rab thugs rje tshad med mnga' ba las/ / mi pham mgon po rnam par snang ba can/ / blo gros zad med yon tan gter mnga' ba/ / 'jam dbyangs bla ma'i zhabs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / phyogs bcur bzhugs pa'i rgyal ba ma lus dang*/ / byang chub sems dang rgyal sras ma lus tshogs/ / rdul gcig steng na rdul snyed bzhugs pa yi/ / bla ma 'phags pa'i tshogs la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Lama who is a precious buddha beyond compare, Blessed by all the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the three times As the essence of their body, speech, and mind: We prostrate at the feet of you of great kindness. The uncontrived and free of elaboration is the lama, the dharmakaya. The lama who is lord of the Dharma is the sambhogakaya. The lama sprung from a lotus stem is the nirmanakaya. We prostrate to Vajradhara of the three kayas. Bhikshu born in the kshatriya clan in Sahor, The abbot-bodhisattva Shantarakshita, Holder of the precepts, expert in all five sciences: We prostrate to you who are endowed with the three trainings. You were emanated by the supreme noble ones, the lords of the three classes of deities, With the intent of establishing the Tibetan people in Dharma: King Songtsen Gampo, Trisong Detsen, and Ralpachen. We prostrate to the ancestral Dharma kings. In Tushita you are known as Spotless Sky, In the land of India as Dipamkara, In the land of snows as Glorious Atisha: We prostrate to you whose fame fills the world. You who will become Pradyota, the seventh buddha, Are cared for by Tara. You attained learning and siddhi, And are known as Shakya Shri Bhadra: We prostrate to the scholar of Kashmir. Out of limitless wisdom and compassion, You were emanated by Maitreya. A treasure of good qualities, your understanding is inexhaustible. We prostrate at the feet of Jamyang Lama. To the assembly of all the conquerors in the ten directions, And every single bodhisattva and buddha’s heir, To the assembly of noble lamas, of whom there are As many on a single atom as there are atoms, we prostrate.

zhes pa'i rjes su/ bde gshegs brgyad kyi bstod pa mkhan po nyid kyis mdzad pa ni/ mtshan gyi me tog rgyas shing dag pa la/ / dpe byad bzang po'i 'bru chags mdzes pa'i sku/ / gang gis mthong thos dran dang dpal gyur pa/ / mtshan gyi rgyal po de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rin chen zla ba pad+mas rab brgyan cing*/ / shes bya kun la mkhas pa'i mkhyen pa 'phags/ / rgya mtsho lta bur zab pa'i sku mnga' ba/ / sgra dbyangs rgyal po de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dzam bu'i chu bo gser ltar lhang nge ba/ / nyi ma stong las lhag pa'i gzi brjid 'bar/ / dri med gser gyi mchod sdong lta bu'i sku/ / gser bzang dri med snang la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mya ngan 'das shing bde ba'i mchog brnyes pa/ / 'gro ba'i sdug bsngal gdung ba zhi mdzad cing*/ / 'gro drug mgon dang dpal du gyur pa yi/ / mya ngan med mchog dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / chos sgra chen pos pha rol rgol ba 'joms/ / rgya mtsho lta bur zab pa'i sku mnga' zhing*/ / 'gro ba'i dug gsum ma lus zhi mdzad pa/ / chos bsgrags rgya mtsho'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / chos kyi blo gros gting dpag dka' ba'i tshul/ / rnam dag chos kyi dbyings la rol mdzad cing*/ / shes bya ma lus mngon sum gzigs pa po/ / chos blo mngon par mkhyen la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'gro ba'i nad gso mdzad pa sman pa'i mchog / baiDUr+ya ltar dwangs pa'i sku mnga' zhing*/ / sku yi 'od kyis 'gro ba sgrol mdzad pa/ / sman pa'i rgyal po de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thugs rje kun la snyoms pa'i bcom ldan 'das/ / mtshan tsam thos pas ngan 'gro'i sdug bsngal skyob/ / dug gsum nad sel sangs rgyas sman gyi bla/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / nyi ma lta bur ma rig mun pa sel/ / zla ba lta bur nyon mongs gdung ba sel/ / dug gsum nad sel sangs rgyas sman gyi bla/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lha mi'i ston pa sman pa'i rgyal po ste/ / bcom ldan 'jig rten gsum la skyabs mdzad pa/ / dug gsum nad sel sangs rgyas sman gyi bla/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / khyod ni 'jig rten gsum gyi sman pa ste/ / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug rtsad nas gcod/ / sems can thams cad bde la rab tu 'god/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / ye shes spyan gyis 'gro ba kun la gzigs/ / thugs rje'i spyan gyis 'gro ba kun la khyab/ / dug gsum nad sel sangs rgyas sman gyi bla/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rlung dang mkhris pa bad kan 'dus pa sogs/ / 'byung ba chen po 'khrugs par gyur pa la/ / nad kyi gnyen po phyag g.yas a ru ra/ / sman pa'i rgyal po khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sku mdog mthing ka ud+pal sngon po 'dra/ / phyag g.yon bdud rtsi'i sman gyi lhung bzed bsnams/ / dug gsum nad sel sangs rgyas sman gyi bla/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / nyes pa rgya mtsho dag ni gzhir spangs nas/ / yon tan rgya mtsho dag gi pha rol son/ / thams cad mkhyen pa lha yi lhar gyur pa/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / smon lam rgya chen yongs su dag gyur pa'i/ / yid bzhin nor bu lta bur gzhan don mdzad/ / dug gsum nad sel sangs rgyas sman gyi bla/ / baiDUr+ya'i 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thabs mkhas thugs rjes shAkya'i rigs su 'khrungs/ / gzhan gyis mi thub bdud kyi dpung 'joms pa/ / gser gyi lhun po lta bur brjid pa'i sku/ / shAkya'i rgyal po de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /zhes dang*/

After that, recite the Praise to the Eight Sugatas composed by the abbot [Shantarakshita] himself: The flowers of your marks are pure and in bloom. Your body is beautified with the emerging fruit of the signs. Whom it is splendid to see, hear or recall to mind: We prostrate to the King of Names. Beautifully adorned with jewels, moon, and lotus, With a noble one’s knowledge of all to be known, You gained a body deep as the ocean: We prostrate to the King of Melodious Sound. Bright as the Jambu river’s gold, Blazing with a brilliance greater than a thousand suns, Your body is like a pillar of flawless gold: We prostrate to Excellent Golden Flawless Appearance. You attained nirvana and supreme happiness. You quelled the anguish of beings’ sufferings. You are the protector of beings of the six realms, and glorious: We prostrate to the Glorious Supreme Sorrow-less One. You conquer opponents with the great sound of the Dharma. Your body is profound as the ocean. You pacified all three of the poisons of beings: We prostrate to Voice of an Ocean of Proclaimed Dharma. With an understanding of Dharma fathomlessly deep, You revel in the pure dharmadhatu. You see directly all that exists, missing nothing: We prostrate to Dharma Mind that Directly Knows. You are the supreme medicine to cure the diseases of beings, With a body pure and clear as vaidurya. You liberate beings with your body’s light: We prostrate to the King of Medicine. Bhagavan whose compassion is equal towards all, Just hearing your name protects against the lower realms’ sufferings. We prostrate to you who cure the disease of the three poisons, Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. Like the sun you dispel the darkness of ignorance. Like the moon you dispel the torment of afflictions. We prostrate to you who cure the disease of the three poisons, Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. A teacher of gods and humans, a king of medicine, Triumphant, you give refuge to the three worlds. We prostrate to you who cure the disease of the three poisons, Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. You are physician to the three worlds, Eradicating desire, hatred, ignorance completely. You bring all beings to complete ease. We prostate to Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. You see all beings with eyes of wisdom. You reach all beings with eyes of compassion. We prostrate to you who cure the disease of the three poisons, Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. In your right hand is a myrobalan fruit, Antidote to diseases from disturbances of the elements, Such as wind, bile, phlegm, and their combinations. We prostrate to you, the King of Medicine. The color of your body is blue, the blue of an utpala flower. Your left hand holds a bowl of medicinal nectar. We prostrate to you who cure the disease of the three poisons, Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. You gave up oceans of faults, from their base. You mastered oceans of good qualities, to their far shores. We prostrate to Vaidurya Light, The All-Knowing One, the God of Gods. Your vast aspirations are perfectly pure. You accomplish others’ aims like a wish-fulfilling jewel. We prostrate to you who cure the disease of the three poisons, Medicine Buddha of Vaidurya Light. Through skill and compassion you took birth in the Shakya clan, You conquered Mara’s forces while others could not. Your body resplendent as a golden Mount Meru, We prostrate to the King of the Shakyas.

chos dkon mchog dang 'khor gyi bstod pa lag len mthong brgyud ni/ ma rig mun sel sgron me'i mchog / sdug bsngal nad sel sman gyi phul/ / dam chos dkon mchog thams cad la/ / phyag 'tshal mchod cing skyabs su mchi/ / gzhon nu'i sku lus 'chang dbang po/ / ye shes sgron me rab brgyan cing*/ / 'jig rten gsum gyi mun sel ba/ / 'jam dpal dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'gro drug 'jigs pa brgyad las skyob mdzad cing*/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho che las sgrol ba'i gru/ / mya ngan 'das sar phyin pa'i ded dpon mchog / sems dpa' skyabs grol mdzad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lcang lo can gyi gnas mchog dam pa nas/ / gsang sngags rig sngags kun gyi bdag po ste/ / log 'dren bgegs kyi tshogs rnams 'joms mdzad pa/ / bcom ldan rdo rje bsnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ / tshangs dang brgya byin rgyal po chen po bzhi/ / rang rang sde bcas mthu dang dpal ldan pa/ / ston pa'i dam chos skyong bar mdzad pa yi/ / lha yi dge bsnyen rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bde gshegs bstan pa srung ba'i dge bsnyen mchog / 'jigs pa'i gzugs dang rngam pa'i cha lugs can/ / bdun 'bum 'khor gyis bskor ba'i bcu gnyis po/ / gnod sbyin sde dpon rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes brjod pas phyag 'tshal zhing*/

Then, praises to the Jewel od Dharma and retinue, which is the practice of the visual tradition. Prostrate as you recite: Supreme lamps to dispel the darkness of ignorance, Superb medicine to cure the disease of suffering, To all the pure Jewels of Dharma: We prostrate, make offerings, and go for refuge. Lord in a youthful bodily form, Adorned with the lamp of wisdom, You dispel the darkness of the three worlds: To Manjushri, we prostrate. A protector from the eight dangers of the six realms, A ship to carry us free of the great ocean of samsara, The supreme captain taking us to a place beyond sorrow: To Bodhisattva Kyabdrol, we prostrate. From the sacred land of Adakavati, Lord of all the classes of tantra and mantra, Destroyer of the hosts of obstructers that lead us astray: To the Bhagavan who holds the vajra, we prostrate. Brahma, Indra, and the Four Great Kings, Each with their retinues, possessed of strength and glory: To the upasaka gods who serve to protect The pure Dharma of our Teacher, we prostrate. The supreme upasakas who guard the Sugata’s teachings Terrifying in form, awe-inspiring in attire, Each surrounded by a retinue of 700,000, To the twelve yaksha generals, we prostrate.

'phags pa'i tshogs de dag thams cad la mchod yon dang byug pa/ me tog dang bdug spos/ mar me dang zhal zas/ rol mo dang sil snyan/ gdugs dang ba dan la sogs pa dngos su ci 'byor pa de dag dang*/ phyogs bcu na bdag pos yongs su ma bzung ba'i lha dang mi'i rdzas dam pa bde ba'i yo byad phun sum tshogs pa thams cad dang*/ gzungs dang rig pa'i mthu dang mos pa'i stobs kyis bskyed pa'i mchod sprin bzang por spyod pa'i smon lam las byung ba rgya mtsho thams cad kyis nam mkha'i mtha' klas pa thams cad bkang ste 'bul lo/ /mchod do/ / bdag cag rnams kyis thog ma ma mchis pa nas 'khor ba na 'khor ba'i tshe rabs thams cad du sdig pa mi dge ba'i las mdor na mi bgyi bar 'os pa'i las ni bgyis/ bgyi bar 'os pa'i las ma bgyis pa la sogs pa dngos sdig ci mchis pa thams cad yang dag par 'chags so/ / dus gsum gyi 'phags pa dang so so'i skye bo'i dge ba mtha' dag gi bsod nams thams cad la rjes su yi rang ngo*/ / phyogs bcu'i rgyal ba thams cad chos kyi 'khor lo bla na med pa bskor bar bskul lo/ / 'jig rten gyi sgron me gang dag mya ngan las 'da' ba'i tshul ston par bzhed pa de dag thams cad la mya ngan las mi 'da' bar 'jig rten gyi don mdzad cing yun ring du bzhugs su gsol bar 'tshal lo/ / zhes brjod pas 'phags pa gdan 'dzoms pa'i mchod pa ci 'byor pa bya/

Then make whatever offerings you have to the noble gathering as you recite: We make offerings and venerate all these assemblies of noble ones, with these actual offering objects, such as oil for anointing, flowers, incense, lamps, food, music, cymbals, parasols, and banners, as well as everything excellent in the ten directions that gives delight and is not claimed by any owner, made of the very best of celestial and human materials. We fill all the endless skies with oceans of clouds of offerings arising from the Aspiration for Excellent Conduct, produced by dharani, the power of the mind, and the strength of our aspirations, and these we offer. We fully confess all the unvirtuous misdeeds we have committed in all our lifetimes, while cycling through samsara since beginningless time: in short, doing what ought not to be done and not doing what ought to be done, and all the misdeeds we ourselves have committed. We rejoice in all the merit produced by all the virtuous acts done in the three times by the noble ones and by ordinary beings. We exhort all the conquerors in the ten directions to turn the unsurpassable wheel of Dharma. We beseech all those lamps of the world wishing to display the deed of passing into nirvana to engage in deeds benefitting the world without passing into nirvana, and to remain long.

de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bdun dang*/ ston pa bcom ldan 'das dpal shAkya thub pa 'khor dang bcas pa spyan drangs te mtshan nas brjod cing phyag 'tshal ba dang*/ mchod cing de dag gi smon lam btab pa dang*/ de dag gi spyan sngar sdig pa bshags pa dang*/ dge ba la rjes su yi rang ba dang*/ chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bar bskul zhing mya ngan las mi 'da' bar gsol ba btab pa dang*/ de dag gi mthu dpal dang byin rlabs kyi stobs kyis/ bdag cag thog ma ma mchis pa'i 'khor ba nas bsags pa'i sdig pa dang sgrib pa thams cad byang zhing dag par gyur cig / lus la nad med pa dang tshe ring bar gyur cig / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dpal phun sum tshogs pa la mnga' brnyes par gyur cig / mthar tshogs gnyis yongs su rdzogs nas rdo rje'i sku chos kyi rgyal po sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi go 'phang brnyes par gyur cig / yul khams thams cad du yang mi nad dang phyugs nad dang lo nyes pa dang dgra'i gnod pa la sogs pa bkra mi shis pa'i bag ci yang mi 'byung bar gyur cig / char chu dus su babs te lo phyugs 'phel zhing rgyas pa dang*/ bde skyid kyi dpal phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan par gyur cig / sems can thams cad kyang bde ba dang ldan te/ zhing khams de dag tu skyes nas de bzhin gshegs pa de dag gi gdams ngag thob ste tshogs gnyis rdzogs nas sangs rgyas par gyur cig / khyad par du yang dam pa'i chos yun ring du gnas shing rgyas par gyur cig /

Then: By invoking the seven tathagatas, arhats, completely perfect buddhas and the Teacher, the Glorious Bhagavan Shakyamuni, together with their retinues, and then reciting their names, making prostrations and offerings; by making the same aspirations as they did; by confessing our misdeeds in their presence; rejoicing in virtue; requesting them to turn the wheel of Dharma and not to pass into parinirvana; and by their splendid strength and the power of their blessings, may all the misdeeds and obscurations we have accumulated in beginningless samsara be cleansed and purified. May our bodies be free of disease and our lives long. May we be possessed of abundant riches, mundane and supramundane. Finally, may we complete the two accumulations and attain a vajra body, the state of a buddha bhagavan, a king of Dharma. Throughout all countries, may there be no human diseases, animal diseases, crop failure, harm by enemies, nor the slightest misfortune of any other kind. May the rains come on time. May crops and livestock flourish and increase, and may there be an abundance of excellent delight. May all beings be happy. May they take birth in the pure lands receive instructions from the tathagatas, and then may they complete the two accumulations and awaken as buddhas. And especially, may the pure Dharma remain long and flourish.

de nas bzod par gsol te/ che ge mos/ bdag cag la sogs pa 'gro ba mang po'i don mdzad par gsol ba'i skabs 'dir bdag cag dus ngan pa'i sems can spyod pa dman zhing ma dag pas ma 'tshal ba dang*/ lus ngag yid gsum nyon mongs pa dang 'dres pa dang*/ mchod pa'i dngos po chung zhing dman pa dang*/ gtsang sbra ma phyed pa dang*/ mdo las byung ba'i cho ga bzhin du ma lcogs pa la sogs pa 'khrul zhing nongs pa thams cad 'phags pa thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa rnams la bzod par gsol zhing mchis na/ thugs brtse bas dgongs te bzod par bzhes shing 'phral dang yun du bdag cag gi sgrib par mi 'gyur bar byin gyis brlab tu gsol/

After that, request forgiveness: On this occasion when we are requesting you to act for the benefit of ourselves and many other beings, I [state your name] ask the forgiveness of you noble ones of great compassion for all the mistakes and errors committed due to the base and impure conduct of us beings of inferior times, such as mixing body, speech, and mind with the kleshas, offering objects that were too few or inferior, not cleaning, and being unable to perform the ritual as stated in the sutra. Please regard us with affection, and forgive us. We request that you grant your blessings that we be free of obscurations now and hereafter.

de nas rjes la gshegs gsol te/ mgon po thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa khyed rnams kyis bdag cag dang sems can thams cad don mdzad lags kyis/ so so'i zhing khams su 'khor dang bcas pa gshegs su gsol/ slar yang sems can don la thugs rjes 'byon par zhu/

Next, the invitation to come again later: Protectors of Great Compassion, acting for our welfare and that of all sentient beings, please proceed to your respective realms with your retinues, and then please return again, out of compassion, for the welfare of sentient beings.

After that, the practice is to recite the Aspiration of Excellent Conduct each time. If the practice is done in one session daily, dismantle the mandala and offerings. Otherwise, if the practice is done two, three, or more times daily as an ongoing retreat, do not dismantle the mandala, but leave it as is and change the offerings. This concise ritual of offering to the seven tathagatas is based on the system of Acharya Bodhisattva (Shantarakshita), incorporating the annotations of Gyaltsap Rinpoche, and applied as in the Kamtsang practice. Please forgive any mistakes. If there is any virtue, it is dedicated for the sake of the teachings and beings. The above was compiled by the sixth All-Knowing Lord (Shamarpa) Chökyi Wangchuk, and then slight damage to the woodblocks was corrected, and references and requisites were inserted. It was prepared for ease of recitation by Karma Araga (Chakme). Set up any thangkas or statues of Medicine Buddha you have. On top of a mandala, place eight heaps of grain and one in the middle, for a total of nine. In front of that, set up eight offering cakes, eight lamps, and place offering water in seven bowls. Rolmo cymbals are played at the time of the music offering. MANGALAM BHAVATU. ŚHUBHAM.

In Sanskrit: Gurupūjakalpanāma In Tibetan: bla ma mchod pa’i cho ga zhes bya ba In English: A Ritual of Offerings to the Gurus I prostrate to the glorious Lion of the Shakyas. From The Collection of Precious Qualities: “The Buddha’s qualities depend on spiritual friends,” Thus spoke the Victor, who has the best of all good qualities. In the words of the Kadampa lords: The first of all instructions Is not to abandon the exalted friend. He is the source and treasury of All qualities such as faith and bodhichitta. Dakpo Rinpoche said, “If you do not receive the guru’s blessings, you will look at the mind essence but not see it. You will grasp but not get it. You will block but not stop it. You will get rid of but not be rid of your perceptions, and smash but not destroy them. Therefore for those who want to gather the accumulations, purify obscurations, pacify obstacles, generate realization, overcome appearances, and perfectly benefit themselves and others, there is nothing to do but serve and supplicate the guru alone.” Mokchokpa said, “If Great Compassion is white, he’s white. If Vajrayogini is red, she’s red. If Hevajra is blue, he’s blue. But wherever I am, I’m never separate from the appearance of my guru, so it seems that buddhahood in a single lifetime is on its way.” Thus the ground of all excellence in this and future lives, the root of all paths, the best means of progress, the guide to higher rebirth and liberation, and the source of all instruction is the guru, the spiritual friend. If you know the reasons why this is so and have appropriate devotion, you will see the meaning of dharmata. From The Supreme Continuum: The ultimate of the self-arisen Is realized only through faith. Therefore strive in the practice of offering to the gurus, the root of all virtue and excellence. The way to do so is: Bless the ground, palace, and offerings. Invite the field of accumulation and welcome it. Offer ablution, drying, adornment, and anointment. Prostrate, make offerings, praise, and confess wrongdoing. Take refuge, generate bodhichitta, rejoice, and request the wheel of Dharma. Request that they remain, dedicate, and declare auspiciousness. These are the twenty branches of Dharma practice. To perform them,

Blessing the ground and palace: Through the power of the truth of the Three Jewels and their blessing; through the power of the completion of the two accumulations; through the power of the natural qualities of the dharmadhatu; through the power of the purification of buddha realms, such as the preparation of pure realms by bodhisattvas; and through the power of our imagination, may this place have all the adornments, features, and excellent qualities of buddha realms. The ground of various jewels is as even as the palm of a hand, broad and vast, soft and pleasant to the touch, unsullied and luminous. Colorful divine flowers that give off the fragrance of snake-heart sandalwood are scattered evenly over it. Bordered by bricks made of jewels and sprinkled with powdered gold, silver, and pearl, it is covered with lithe and graceful flowers such as utpalas, kumudas, and lotuses. It is beautified by lakes, ponds, and pools filled with water possessing the eight qualities, where water fowl swim and float with delight, giving forth their sweet calls. Bejeweled wish-fulfilling trees are hung with divine gems, strings of pearls, and jewels, and bent with budding flowers and lovely, fresh, ripe fruits. Strings of golden bells ring out the sound of genuine Dharma. Upon this formally arranged and finely adorned ground is a great palace, blazing greatly with the seven jewels. Their great light-rays utterly fill innumerable world-realms. The palace has countless distinct features and is of immeasurable vastness. It is a place that perfectly transcends the three realms. It utterly transcends the world. It has arisen from supramundane roots of virtue. It is utterly pure and has the character of masterful awareness. It is the abode of the tathagatas. It has the Sangha of bodhisattvas. Innumerable gods, nagas, yakshas, gandharvas, asuras, garudas, kinnaras, great serpents, humans, and non-human beings move about within it. It is founded on the joy and great bliss of the taste of Dharma. It is a place where all beings’ benefit is perfectly accomplished. It is free from the stain of any harm by kleshas. All maras have been vanquished there. It has the array of the tathagatas, features superior to all others. It is emancipation through great recollection, intelligence, and realization. It is the mount on which shamatha and vipashyana ride. It is entered by the gates of liberation—emptiness, absence of attributes, and absence of wishes. In the center of a great palace supported by a precious king of lotuses decorated with infinite qualities there are lotus seats atop lion thrones. On them are the Teacher—the Bhagavan Shakyamuni—and a retinue of great masters from India and Tibet, including Marpa, Milarepa, and Gampopa; the great siddha Khyungpo Naljor and other masters of the oral lineage of Golden Dharma; Mey, Ngok, Tsön, and other masters of the oral lineage of explanations; Rechungpa and other masters of the whispered lineage; and masters of the four elder and eight younger practice lineages, all surrounded by many great masters and spiritual friends. All the noble beings in this great assembly have beautiful seats that accord with their own especial aspirations and prominence.

Blessing the offerings: Everywhere outside and inside may there be all the appropriate and fine articles used by gods and humans. May there be excellent, finely prepared food of many varieties with aromas pleasant to inhale, flavors delightful to taste, textures pleasant to swallow, and a pleasing appearance. May there be a variety of the most perfect raiments, jewelry, musical instruments, and so forth. May there be abundantly ornamented clouds and oceans of offerings that fill all space, like those found in The Sutra in Three Sections and The Aspiration for Excellent Conduct. May all the noble ones take their seats, bless these offerings, accept them, and enjoy them.
